Definition: This category concerns security deposit/charge issues that may arise for tenants in public housing. This includes questions about how much housing authorities can charge for a deposit, how to get assistance to pay it, how it can be returned, and what can be deducted from it.

Title: Poor living conditions in a rented home
Definition: This category concerns problems that a person may have as a tenant in a rental home. This includes issues with heat, air, water, plumbing, pests, major appliances, locks, doors, or other essential features. It may also be known as a "Warranty of Habitability" issue.

Title: Poor living conditions in a federally subsidized (Section 8) home
Definition: This category concerns problems that a person may have as a tenant in a federally-subsidized (Section 8 voucher) rented home. This includes issues with heat, air, water, plumbing, pests, major appliances, locks, doors, or other essential features. It may also be known as a "Warranty of Habitability" or "Quality Standards" issue.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1612209], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1641200]

Title: Poor living conditions in a rental subsidized with rural rental assistance
Definition: This category concerns problems that a person may have as a tenant in a rental that is subsidized by a federal rural rental assistance program (formerly known as FMHA Housing program). This includes issues with heat, air, water, plumbing, pests, major appliances, locks, doors, or other essential features. It may also be known as a "Warranty of Habitability" issue.

Title: Poor living conditions in public housing
Definition: This category covers issues that a person may have as a tenant in public housing, when the government/housing authority is their landlord. This includes issues with heat, air, water, plumbing, pests, major appliances, locks, doors, or other essential features. It may also be known as a "Warranty of Habitability" issue, or as a Quality Standards issue.

Title: Housing code compliance
Definition: This category concerns how a tenant can raise code compliance violations if they think their landlord is providing a rental home that goes against the codes for housing quality standards. It also includes the protections that tenants may have about rent control or protection from retaliation if their landlord is in violation of the housing code.

Title: Rent charges, increases, and control
Definition: This category covers issues that a tenant may have with rent levels for their home, including how much rent they have to pay, how much it can be increased by, and protections they may have based on local laws or housing programs. It covers private rentals, subsidized rentals, and public housing.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1630800], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1630899]

Title: Rent issues in public housing
Definition: This category covers issues that individual tenants or housing project groups may have with rent in public housing. This includes how the rent levels are defined, how the tenant's financial situation affects the rents, and how rent may be increased.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640500], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640599]

Title: Rent issues in federally subsidized rentals
Definition: This category covers issues that tenants in federally subsidized (Section 8) rentals might have with rent levels, including how they are calculated, what ceiling rents are, what allowances they may have for utilities, how rents might be increased, and other issues.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1610700], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1610799], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1611100]

Title: Rent issues in rural assistance subsidized homes
Definition: This category covers issues that tenants in homes subsidized by rural rental assistance programs (formerly FMHA programs) might have with rent levels, including how they are calculated, what ceiling rents are, what allowances they may have for utilities, how rents might be increased, and other issues.

Title: Challenging a landlord's security deposit deductions
Definition: This category concerns how a tenant may challenge the deductions that a landlord takes from their security deposits, like for repairs or damages to the home after the tenant moves out. This includes possibly raising claims under the Unfair Trade Practices law, that the landlord misrepresented the repairs needed, in order to claim financial damages.

Title: Challenging a federally subsidized rental's living conditions
Definition: This category concerns options a tenant or government agencies may have to challenge a landlord's housing quality and affordability for federally subsidized rentals. This includes raising claims of Unfair Trade Practices, of fraudulently presenting rentals as fair, safe, and affordable, and subjecting tenants to uninhabitable and dangerous conditions. It also covers formal grievance procedures of raising problems to the local housing authority or other government actors.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1612208], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1690940], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1610500], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1611000]

Title: Landlord access to a rental
Definition: This category covers issues a tenant might have with how and when the landlord can access their rental home, and how they have 'quiet enjoyment' to their home. This covers private rentals, subsidized rentals, and public housing. It includes issues of landlords coming onto the property too frequently, unnecessarily, or without proper notice.

Title: Disruptions to 'quiet enjoyment' of a rental
Definition: This category concerns issues a tenant might have, that prevent them from their basic rights of 'quiet enjoyment' of their home. This includes issues with ongoing noises or behaviors from neighbors, maintenance work that takes significantly longer than expected, pests making noises, or landlords calling or entering the property too frequently or without notice.

Title: Title and ownership defenses against an eviction
Definition: This category covers issues a tenant may raise if sued for eviction, which challenges the landlord's claim to have title or ownership of the home. This might be called a Claim of Title defense.

Title: Being a defendant in an eviction lawsuit
Definition: This category covers issues and options for being a defendant in an eviction or unlawful detainer lawsuit. These options, obligations, and processes change depending on local state and city jurisdictions.

Title: Being a plaintiff in an eviction lawsuit
Definition: This category is about the requirements, options, and procedures that a landlord must follow while a plaintiff in an eviction (or unlawful detainer) lawsuit.

Title: Having a Jury Trial in an eviction lawsuit
Definition: This category covers if and how a person can request that their eviction lawsuit be heard by a jury (rather than just by a judge).

Title: Raising Appeals to an eviction lawsuit's judgment
Definition: This category covers how a tenant or landlord can appeal the judge's final decisions or orders in an eviction lawsuit.

Title: Nonpayment of Rent eviction case procedure
Definition: This category covers how a court process for an eviction based on nonpayment of rent works, including if a tenant can be sided, how they must be given notice, if they are able to pay back rent to make the lawsuit end, what defenses they might have, and what possible judgments and outcomes may be.

Title: Holdover eviction cases
Definition: This category covers a certain type of eviction lawsuit, a holdover case. These are more complicated than nonpayment of rent eviction cases. They could involve the landlord trying to remove a tenant who is not a direct tenant (like a roommate), or trying to remove a tenant for lease violations or other issues.

Title: Canceling (or setting aside) an Eviction Order
Definition: This category covers options that a tenant might have after a court has ruled in an eviction case, ordering on the side of the landlord that they can remove the tenant from the home. This includes how to file a motion to set aside (or cancel) the eviction order, based on a legal reason why the order should never have been issued. This might be for problems with how the case procedure went, landlord fraud, mistake or surprise, new evidence, or that the tenant has already moved out.

Title: Challenging a landlord for a 'constructive eviction'
Definition: This category covers how a tenant can challenge a landlord for trying to evict them illegally, by making it so difficult to live in the home that they must leave. This might involve shutting off heat or water, changing the locks, harassing tenants, failing to make repairs, or other harmful actions. The category covers what a tenant must gather and prove to be able to make a 'constructive eviction' claim, what kinds of landlord behavior amounts to a constructive eviction, and what options and outcomes might result.

Title: Jurisdiction issues around an eviction case
Definition: This category covers which level and geographical area of court has jurisdiction to hear an eviction case between a landlord and tenant.

Title: Retaliatory Eviction defenses against an eviction
Definition: This category covers how a tenant may defend themselves against an eviction action that they believe was filed in retaliation for exercising their rights as a tenant. This could be for having reported housing code violations, complaining about unsafe living conditions, exercising their First Amendment rights, or using their (possible) state rights to withhold or deduct rent to fix poor living conditions. This category covers how a defendant can stop an eviction by raising a defense that the eviction is illegal under anti-retaliation laws.

Title: Tenant Rights, Organizations, and Participation
Definition: This category covers the basic rights that tenants have, their ability to organize or unionize, their ability to participate in the housing market or government agencies, and other related issues. This includes how a tenant in public or subsidized housing has rights to participate in decisions about the housing quality and modernization. It also covers rights around raising grievances and advocating for themselves.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1631300], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1631100]

Title: Tenants' participation and organization in subsidized housing
Definition: This category covers how tenants who live in federally subsidized housing (like Section 8 voucher holders) can participate in the housing program, raise grievances, advocate for themselves, and organize into unions or other groups.

Title: Tenants' participation and organization in public housing
Definition: This category covers the rights that tenants have when living in public housing, including their right to participate in decisions and modernization of the housing, their ability to raise grievances and to organize to advocate for themselves.

Title: Leases & Rental Agreements for a rental home
Definition: This category covers the process of receiving, understanding, negotiating, and signing a lease between a landlord and tenant. This includes how a tenant can ensure the lease is fair, raise any objections, protect their rights, and deal with other issues with the lease. It can also be about how to understand, modify, or challenge a lease after signing it.

Title: Leases for a federally subsidized home
Definition: This category covers the process of receiving, understanding, negotiating, and signing a lease between a landlord and tenant for federally subsidized (like Section 8 housing). This includes how a tenant can ensure the lease is fair, raise any objections, protect their rights, and deal with other issues with the lease. It can also be about how to understand, modify, or challenge a lease after signing it.

Title: Landlord access to a federally subsidized rental
Definition: This category covers when and whether a landlord can come into a rented home that's subsidized by federally funding, like Section 8 vouchers. It covers issues when tenants have a problem that landlords come without notice or are entering their home.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [ 1612303], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1612300], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1612399], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1612302]

Title: Landlord or Housing Authority access to a public housing rental
Definition: This category covers when and whether a landlord (or member of a public housing authority) can come into a public housing rental. It covers issues when tenants have a problem that landlords or housing authority representatives come without notice or are entering their home. This can be linked to the tenant's right to exclude people from their rental home.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1642010], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1642000], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1642099], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1642030]

Title: Late fees, penalties, other charges for a rental home
Definition: This category covers issues a tenant might have when a landlord charges them fees for paying their rent late, includes other penalties, or charges them more money than they expected for renting the home.

Title: Landlord locking-out or shutting off utilities
Definition: This category covers renters' options and rights if their landlord changes their locks, blocks their entry to their home, or if they shut off their utilities while the renter is still living there. These actions may be an illegal eviction, that the renter can take the landlord to court for.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1630600], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1070800]

Title: Landlord taking property for rent owed
Definition: This category covers what options and rights a tenant may have if their landlord takes or detains their property. This is typically when the landlord feels the tenant owes them rent or other money.

Title: Rent Control
Definition: This category covers issues around rent control, for tenants and landlords who live in an area with rent control policies. These policies, that are often put into law by city or county ordinances, limit the rent that landlords can charge to tenants, and how much and how often they can raise rent. This category covers questions about how people can complain about overcharges, deal with rent control laws, and deal with eviction and successions.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1630800], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1630899]

Title: Overcharges of rent in a rent control area
Definition: This category covers how a tenant can complain of an overcharge, that is in violation of rent control policies in their local area. It also covers how landlords can respond, and how an overcharge complaint is processed and resolved.

Title: Determining if a home is covered by rent control
Definition: This category is about how to determine if a rental home is covered by rent control protections or not. This might be known as a 'coverage' issue. The coverage might depend on the location, age, and situation of the house.

Title: Rent control agencies' practices
Definition: This category covers how the organization that enforces rent control -- like a local rent board -- behaves, including how they they hear disputes and enforce the control laws.

Title: Eviction limits under Rent Control laws
Definition: This category covers the specific rules and protections that rent control laws (or ordinances) may give to tenants facing eviction. Rent control laws might limit the reasons that landlords can evict a tenant, and give extra defenses to a tenant who has been sued.

Title: Rent control jurisdictions
Definition: This category covers whether a certain geographical area has rent control laws or not.

Title: Pet fees, deposits, and rent
Definition: This category covers whether and how a landlord can charge a tenant an extra fee for having pets in the apartment. This includes things like pet fees, pet deposits, and pet rent. Rent control laws may explicitly prohibit these kinds of fees.

Title: Succession rights and process in Rent Control homes
Definition: This category covers how rent control or rent-stabilization laws determine how one tenant can take a home over from another. This includes succession rights eligibility, the landlord's ability to change the rent, when a family member can take over the home at the same rent level, how to claim these rights, and how to challenge a claimed succession.

Title: Local regulations of rental housing
Definition: This category covers state, city, and other local rules that control how property-owners can rent out homes.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1631400], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1631404]

Title: City regulations of renting a home
Definition: This category covers local city regulations of who and how a private home can be rented.

Title: State regulations of rental housing
Definition: This category covers state rules on who can rent their private home out, and how they can do so.

Title: Homelessness and Housing Insecurity
Definition: This category covers issues, rights, protections, and services for people who are experiencing housing instability or homelessness.

Title: Affordable Housing development
Definition: This category covers issues around the development of new affordable housing units.

Title: Rent Ceilings or Flat Rent for public housing
Definition: This category concerns upper limits on what rents can be charged in public housing. It also may be known as the Flat Rent -- the most amount of rent you may be charged in public housing. This covers how this ceiling is calculated and when a tenant may use the flat rent rather than income-based rent amounts.

Title: Income-based rent rates for public housing
Definition: This category covers how a person's rent for public housing is calculated, including what their annual income is, what parts of their income is disregarded, and other formulas that are used.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640520], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640530], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640540], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1690500]

Title: Utility allowances and charges for public or subsidized housing
Definition: This category covers how tenants of public housing or subsidized housing may be able to deduct a monthly utility allowance, if the utilities are not already included in their rent. This covers how much this allowance might be, according to a local housing authority and how it affects the rental amount that the person may have to pay.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640550], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640900], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1611700], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1610702]

Title: Rent increases in public housing
Definition: This category covers if and how rent can be increased in public housing. This could also be called project-wide rental increases.

Title: Safety and security in public housing
Definition: This category is about issues around public housing tenants may have with physical safety and security in their homes. This includes their rights, ability to raise grievances, and obligations of housing authorities to deal with issues of safety.

Title: Public Housing sites, rehabilitation, and demolition
Definition: This category covers issues people might have when public housing is built, demolished, relocated, or other issues as to where it is located. This could be issues around the rights of tenants when a housing unit is being demolished or relocated. It is also about the legal process and requirements of how sites are decided upon, and whether there is permission for demolition.

Title: Site selection for public housing
Definition: This category covers how sites are decided on for public housing, and what rights people have to participate in this process.

Title: Demolition of public housing
Definition: This category covers tenants' rights and options when their public housing unit is being torn down or otherwise demolished.

Title: Relocation rights and assistance for public housing
Definition: This category covers rights, options, and assistance that tenants in public housing might have, if their home is being demolished, rehabilitated, converted, or acquired.

Title: Employment opportunities (Section 3) for public and subsidized housing contracts
Definition: This category covers the Section 3 Rule about how public housing agencies must employ people who either live in public housing or are low-income, when they are contracting for improvements to public housing or other projects.

Title: Hope VI program to revitalize public housing
Definition: This category covers issues and questions around the US government's Hope VI program to rehabilitate public housing projects through new grants, demolition, planning, and other efforts.

Title: Getting public housing
Definition: This category covers the options, eligibility standards, and process of being admitted to live in public housing rentals.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640110], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640199]

Title: Eligibility and Selection Criteria for public housing
Definition: This category covers who is eligible to apply for public housing, and how it will be determined if they will be admitted for housing or not. It includes the local housing authorities' definitions of specific admissions criteria.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640110], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1640160]

Title: Preferences in who gets public housing
Definition: This category covers what preferences a housing authority might have in deciding who gets public housing, and how wait list positions for public housing are determined. This might be on residency past and plans, or other factors.

Title: Residency requirements for public housing
Definition: This category covers the requirements that a housing authority might have for possible renters, about how long they have lived in the geographic area or how long they are planning to stay.

Title: Immigrants' eligibility for housing programs
Definition: This category covers if and how non-US citizens may be able to access public housing, subsidized housing vouchers, emergency assistance, and other programs that help them with the cost of their housing.

Title: Having visitors in public housing
Definition: This category covers a public housing tenant's right to have guests or others in their home, when there might be limits on this, and how a tenant can protect their rights.

Title: Low Income Housing Tax Credit to build affordable housing
Definition: This category covers questions and options for those interested in possibly building low-income housing, or rehabilitating existing units, to provide affordable rental housing for low- and moderate-income tenants. It also covers renters' and residents' rights regarding these development projects.

Title: Single Room Occupancy housing options
Definition: This category concerns options and rights for tenants in single room occupancy units, that lets low-income tenants have affordable housing.

Title: Tenant options when landlord is in foreclosure or bankruptcy
Definition: This category covers what a tenant can do when their landlord's property is in foreclosure, or if their landlord is in the bankruptcy process. It covers what their rights are, what happens if they face eviction based on their landlord's situation, how their lease may change, or if there are new owners of the property.

Title: Housing discrimination based on disability
Definition: This category covers protections, rights, and options for people who are concerned they may have been discriminated against based on their disability.

Title: Housing discrimination based on national origin
Definition: This category concerns the legal options and rights a person may have if they have experienced discrimination around housing based on their national origin or apparent ethnicity. This could be when they were trying to rent a home, get housing assistance, take out a mortgage, buy a home, or other housing-related activities. It includes the practice of redlining.

Title: Housing Discrimination based on gender or sexuality
Definition: This category concerns the legal options and rights a person may have if they have experienced discrimination around housing based on their gender or sexuality. This could be when they were trying to rent a home, get housing assistance, take out a mortgage, buy a home, or other housing-related activities.

Title: Housing discrimination based on familial status (having children, being pregnant, or adopting)
Definition: This category concerns the legal options and rights a person may have if they have experienced discrimination around housing based on their having children, intending to have children, being pregnant, or in the process of adoption. This could be when they were trying to rent a home, get housing assistance, take out a mortgage, buy a home, or other housing-related activities.

Title: Rental protections for those with HIV/AIDS
Definition: This category covers protections, including from local state and city rules, regarding people living with HIV/AIDS. This could be about protection from discrimination, housing assistance programs, homelessness prevention, access to therapies and services, and other rules.

Title: Religious Freedoms and Discrimination
Definition: This category covers protections and rights of people based on their belonging to an organized religious group, or based on their religious or moral beliefs. It covers issues around harassment, discrimination, interference with practicing of religion, reasonable accommodation, dressing and grooming, and other issues.

Title: Housing discrimination based on religion
Definition: This category concerns the legal options and rights a person may have if they have experienced discrimination around housing based on their apparent or actual religion. This could be when they were trying to rent a home, get housing assistance, take out a mortgage, buy a home, or other housing-related activities.

Title: Housing discrimination based on source of income/voucher subsidies
Definition: This category covers discrimination that a person might face when trying to rent a home, based on the source of their income to pay for this home -- like a Section 8 or Housing Choice Voucher. This includes what a person may do to protect themselves against this kind of discrimination, what rights they have, and how they can assert their rights if they feel they are facing discrimination. This can be known as 'No Section 8' policies.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1660300], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1612100]

Title: Having visitors to federally subsidized rental home
Definition: This category covers tenants' rights, options, and limits to have visitors to their home that is subsidized by federal rental assistance, like a Section 8 or Housing Choice Voucher.

Title: Getting a Housing Choice (Section 8) voucher for federally subsidized rental
Definition: This category covers if and how a person can get federal subsidies to rent a home, like getting a Section 8 or Housing Choice Voucher.

Title: Recertifying/reporting changes to income and family for Section 8 voucher
Definition: This category covers how a tenant receiving a Section 8 or Housing Choice Voucher subsidy can recertify their income and family breakdown every year, and how they can report changes during the year if their family or income changes.

Title: Income-based rent rates for federally subsidized housing
Definition: This category covers issues in how to calculate the rent/assistance levels that a tenant getting federally subsidized housing has, including how their income is defined, how rent is defined, what income is disregarded, and what utility allowances they are given.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1610704], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1610701], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1610705], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1610702]

Title: Rent ceilings or Flat Rent rates for federally subsidized rentals
Definition: This category concerns upper limits on what rents can be charged for federally subsidized homes. It also may be known as the Flat Rent -- the most amount of rent you may be charged. This covers how this ceiling is calculated and when a tenant may use the flat rent rather than income-based rent amounts.

Title: Housing Quality Standards for federally subsidized rentals
Definition: This category covers the government-mandated standards that all rentals that qualify for housing choice vouchers, or Section 8 vouchers, must comply with. This includes issues of when the home is on the rental market, and its ongoing maintenance.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1612400], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1610900]

Title: Termination of a federal rental subsidy
Definition: This category covers the process and rights of a tenant who is facing termination of their rental subsidy, like their Section 8 or Housing Choice Voucher.

Title: Subsidized Housing Removal, Conversion, or Preservation
Definition: This category concerns options, rights, and legal strategies that are available when landlords consider removing rental homes from affordable or subsidized housing programs. This also covers notification and protections that must be given to tenants with federal subsidies and vouchers, if the landlord is planning to remove or demolish subsidized housing units.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1612000], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1612099], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1612202]

Title: Landlord Opting out of federal subsidies program
Definition: This category covers whether and how a landlord can decide to remove their home from inclusion in federally subsidized rent programs, like the Section 8/Housing Choice Voucher program. It covers the rights that tenants might have, notice that landlords must give, and possible housing authority or other action the landlords might face.

Title: Termination of 'Troubled Properties' as federally subsidized rentals
Definition: This category concerns what happens when a housing authority or other government agency determines that a rental unit that's associated with Section 8 or other housing subsidies is 'troubled', in that its living conditions do not meet quality standards. This can include the removal of the Section 8 contract, or repairs of the troubled properties -- and this category covers what rights and options tenants have in this process.

Title: Relocating with a federal rent subsidy voucher
Definition: This category covers a tenant's rights and processes to relocate to another home when they use a Section 8 or Housing Choice Voucher to help pay their rent. This includes how they might move if their home is being demolished or converted, if they need to move to a different state, or otherwise.

Title: Safety and security issues in subsidized housing
Definition: This category covers tenants' rights and options when they are concerned about their personal safety and security while living in a rental home with assistance from Section 8, housing choice vouchers, or other subsidized housing programs.

Title: Federal subsidies to buy a home (Homeownership Voucher Program)
Definition: This category concerns a Section 8 or Housing Choice Voucher option to use housing assistance to cover homeownership costs (rather than rental costs). It covers eligibility factors, work and income requirements, time restrictions, and other process to follow to use the voucher program to become a homeowner.

Title: Family members with money, criminal, and other issues
Definition: This category covers issues that a person might have related to a family member who is involved in criminal activity, money and debt problems, and other scenarios that might carry liability or dangers for the person. It covers issues about whether a person might be responsible for a family member's debt, problematic behavior, crimes, or other issues, and what obligations a person has if their family member is involved in irresponsible or criminal behavior.

Title: Lead Paint and Poisoning
Definition: This category covers options and rights for people who have encountered lead paint in their homes or in other buildings, and may have issues with poisoning from it.

Title: Zoning and Land Use of oneâ€™s property
Definition: This category covers issues a property owner might have with dealing with local government, to get approvals for what they might do with their property. It might include issues around dealing with government's zoning designations, redevelopment or additions, environmental issues, selling or acquiring properties, or other issues.

Title: Property Taxes
Definition: This category covers issues that a homeowner might have around paying their taxes for their property. This category covers how the taxes are calculated, how to pay them, and how to deal with disputes around them.

Title: Property Tax Appeals, Refunds and Abatements
Definition: This category covers options for property owners who believe they may have been charged with property taxes at an incorrect assessment, or with other problems. This includes options to appeal a property valuation or request a refund of the taxes they've paid for a property.

Title: Another person (receiver) taking over from a landlord
Definition: This category covers the options of tenants to get a 'Receiver' or a court-appointed party to take over from a landlord who is in foreclosure or having serious problems with a lender. For example, a tenant may be notified that they now should pay rent to the receiver, not to the landlord, because of a court appointment of this receiver.

Title: Mortgages and other financing for a home
Definition: This category covers issues that a homeowner might have with taking out a mortgage, finding support and opportunities, dealing with scams, keeping up on their obligations, and understanding their options if problems arise.

Title: Federally-Subsidized Mortgage Loans
Definition: This category covers issues homeowners might have with mortgage loans that are federally subsidized. This might include issues about who is eligible for these mortgages, restrictions on them, protections for mortgage-holders, relief programs, and other options. It might be from agencies like HUD, Federal Housing Authority, Federal Housing Finance Agency, Federal Home Loan Bank System, Freddie Mac, or Fannie Mae.

Title: HUD-Insured Mortgages
Definition: This category includes options for homeowners who have mortgages that are insured by the HUD agency, or the Federal Housing Authority. It includes how to deal with problems if there are collections or foreclosure issues.

Title: Mortgages for Veterans
Definition: This category covers mortgage options for veterans and military service members, including opportunities to get a more favorable mortgage, protections, obligations, and dealing with problems that may arise.

Title: Mortgage Rescue Scams
Definition: This category is about possible scams a homeowner might face when they are facing collections or foreclosure, and they are offered services or help by groups claiming to be HUD or other government agencies -- or who are charging fees for what should be free services. They could also be posing as lawyers or other groups who promise they can help save a home from foreclosure.

Title: Stopping a foreclosure through a 'redemption' (paying off loan in full)
Definition: This category covers the option for a homeowner to 'redeem' their property within a certain time period in a foreclosure process, by paying off their debt or reimbursing the person who bought the property at the foreclosure sale. The options vary by state, about whether this redemption period is only before a foreclosure sale, or after the sale as well.

Title: Stopping a foreclosure by reinstating (catching up with) the loan
Definition: This category covers options for a homeowner who wants to stop a foreclosure, by 'reinstating' their loan through paying back money they owe (but not the full loan), and then keep up their monthly payments and other fees. States may have different deadlines for when reinstatement may occur, and different lenders may have different policies on reinstating the loan. This category covers how you can use reinstatement as a defense against foreclosure, and also contesting an incorrect reinstatement quote from the lender.

Title: Reverse Mortgages (loans using home equity conversion)
Definition: This category covers issues that a homeowner might face if they take out a reverse mortgage, in which they receive money based on putting up their home as equity. This might be called Home Equity Conversion Mortgages. This category covers who is eligible for reverse mortgages, what repayment obligations are, what happens if someone defaults on them, what happens if a spouse/co-owner dies, and what scams might be.

Title: Dividing (Partition) a home with another owner
Definition: This category covers options for when there are multiple property owners, how to divide the land or home with the other people. This might be with a sibling, friend, partner, or spouse.  This covers options the person has to go to court for a 'partition' to officially divide their ownership rights and the property with an agreement they all live by.

Title: Paying for a home through a Bond/Contract for Deed
Definition: This category covers options for someone who wants to pay for a home through borrowing money, and the borrower keeps the deed and the legal title to the house (and the borrower has physical possession of the house). It is usually known as a Bond for Deed or Contract for Deed arrangement. This includes dealing with consequences if the buyer defaults on the payments, what happens when the buyer makes improvements to the home,  lawsuits that might result from using this bond/contract.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1620650], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1620300]

Title: Deeds for a home
Definition: This category covers issues with drafting, revising, transferring, or dealing with problems with a deed (the legal document about ownership) for a home. This typically done when a home property is being sold and transferred. This covers what kind of deeds are needed, how it is written, how it is recorded, and to deal with other problems.

Title: Closing on a home sale
Definition: This category covers issues with the closing of sale process of a home. This could include dealing with problems with the home sale, like liens or debts, unclear title, pests, defects in the home inspection, low appraisals, and other issues. This includes options for backing out of a home purchase, what documents are required, and what other issues and protections are possible.

Title: Cooperatives, Condominiums, and Homeowners Associations
Definition: This category covers issues that a person might have when they own a home that's part of a cooperative, condominium, or homeowners association. It includes dealing with governing boards, dealing with complaints and violations,  problems with other homeowners, control of decision-making, and other issues.

Title: Mobile Homes
Definition: This category covers issues with owning or renting a mobile home, or living in a mobile home park.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1650000], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1650300], Legal Server Index Taxonomy [LS002-00065], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [65]

Title: Owning a mobile home
Definition: This category covers legal issues that a mobile homeowner might have, when their mobile home is in a mobile home park, or on private land.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1650100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1650200]

Title: Renting in a Mobile Home Park
Definition: This category covers rights and options that tenants of a mobile home might have, in a mobile home park. This also includes special rules around eviction or other problems.

Title: Mortgage Predatory Lending
Definition: This category covers options and issues with possible predatory lending practices around mortgages. This includes what qualifies as predatory lending, using predatory lending as a defense to a foreclosure, options for a victim of predatory lending, or other issues.
Taxonomies: Legal Server Index Taxonomy [LS002-06800], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [68]

Title: Eligibility and Applications for SNAP (food stamp) benefits
Definition: This category covers how to apply for SNAP (or food stamp) benefits, who is eligible for it, how to follow the process, and how to deal with issues that may come up during the application process.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1730200], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1730400]

Title: Emergency SNAP (food stamp) benefits
Definition: This category covers how a person might get emergency food benefits through an expedited application and quick availability. It also includes how long the emergency benefits will last.

Title: Determining eligibility for SNAP (food stamp) benefits
Definition: This category covers how it is determined if you qualify for SNAP (food stamp) benefits, including how assets are determined, what size the household is, and other factors are evaluated.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1730400], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1730300], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1730800]

Title: Expedited issuance of SNAP benefits
Definition: This category covers options for certain people to get their SNAP benefits application approved more quickly, and have access to the benefits sooner. This includes expedited eligibility for households based on income, housing security, jobs as a migrant farm work, or other demographic categories.

Title: Electronic Benefits Transfer (EBT) system and cards
Definition: This category covers issues a person might have when trying to get their SNAP benefits using an Electronic Benefits Transfer card or process. This can be about using a card out of state, having it being blocked, a requirement for a photo card, paying card fees, getting replacements, or bugs in the system.

Title: Fraud in getting SNAP benefits
Definition: This category covers what constitutes 'fraud' when applying for or continuing to receive SNAP (food stamp) benefits, and what rights and options a person has if they are being investigated or accused of engaging in fraud around SNAP.

Title: Being charged with Intentional Program Violations of SNAP
Definition: This category covers what happens if a person receiving SNAP benefits is accused of an 'intentional program violation' of the program, because they were overpaid, they lied to the agency, they did not give all facts about their case, they used the food stamps in inappropriate ways, or they sold food stamps for cash. This category covers what process a person gets if they are accused, what punishments they face, and how they can respond to this.

Title: Underpayment of SNAP benefits
Definition: This category concerns a person's options if they think they are not being paid enough in SNAP benefits, and how to ensure they are paid correctly.

Title: Overpayment and Recoupment of SNAP benefits
Definition: This category covers options and rights a person has if the SNAP agency decides it has been overpaying benefits and attempts to recoup some of the benefits that had been previously issued.

Title: Reduction or Termination of SNAP benefits
Definition: This category covers the process, options, and consequences of having one's SNAP benefits reduced or terminated. It includes options for having them reinstated or stopping the termination.

Title: Immigrants' Eligibility for SNAP benefits
Definition: This category covers questions that non-US citizens may have about whether they can receive SNAP benefits, what happens if they apply, what categories of immigrants may qualify to receive them, and concerns they may have in applying.

Title: Eligibility for unemployment benefits if you quit
Definition: This category covers a person's ability to get unemployment benefits if they have quit their job. The options will vary by state, and by the question about whether the person quit the job with 'good cause' or not. This category also covers whether the person quit 'voluntarily' or not.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1760900], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1761000], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1761100]

Title: Termination of Unemployment Benefits
Definition: This category covers the process, standards, and options for when unemployment benefits can be terminated. It can also cover a person's rights to contest this decision, and try to get benefits reinstated.

Title: Termination of unemployment benefits for turning down a job
Definition: This category covers whether a person's unemployment benefits might be terminated if they turn down a job offer, including whether the job meets the standard of 'Suitable Work' for them.

Title: Termination of unemployment benefits for unavailability for work
Definition: This category covers what happens if a person faces termination of their benefits because they are not available for full-time work, because of other obligations, volunteer work, part time work, or other factors.

Title: Eligibility for unemployment benefits after misconduct
Definition: This category covers if a person who has lost their job can get unemployment, if there are allegations of misconduct or gross misconduct at their previous job. This covers what a state's criteria is for what counts as 'gross misconduct', and how an employee can respond if they are accused of misconduct and denied benefits because of it.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1760800], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1761700]

Title: Unemployment benefits hearings to contest a decision
Definition: This category covers the options to request a hearing if a person disagrees about a decision about their eligibility for unemployment benefits, or termination of them.

Title: Overpayment and Recoupment of unemployment benefits
Definition: This category covers what happens if a person is notified that they have been receiving incorrect amounts of unemployment benefits, including penalties they might face, recoupment process, ways to pay it back, ways to contest the decision, or dealing with allegations of fraud.

Title: Being a Plaintiff in lawsuit (suing someone)
Definition: This category covers the options, process, and obligations of a person who is suing another person or entity, for a harm from an injury that has happened.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1940100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2024400]

Title: Being a Defendant in a lawsuit (being sued)
Definition: This category covers the options, rights, and obligations of a person who is being sued in court for an injury (or tort) that another person alleges has happened. This includes how the court process will work, how a person can defend themselves, and what consequences they might face.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1940200], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2024400]

Title: Conservatorship of an adult's financial affairs
Definition: This category is about some states' options of getting a conservatorship of another adult's financial matters, when they are unable to make decisions for themselves. In some states, it may be called a Limited Conservatorship -- either of the 'person' when it's about the personal needs, or about the 'estate' when it's about financial needs.

Title: Joint Property issues in a guardianship/conservatorship
Definition: This category covers issues when the person under the guardianship or conservatorship co-owns property with other people.

Title: Standby guardianship plan for a child
Definition: This category covers the option for parents to appoint another to take care of their child if they become incapacitated, they die, they face immigration actions, or otherwise are unable to care for their child suddenly. They do not give up their parental rights, and they may revoke their consent to this standby guardianship at any time. Typically this can be established with a signed document and witnesses, but without a court process.

Title: Short-term Temporary Guardianship of a child
Definition: This category covers legal options for a parent who wants another adult to be the guardian for their child for a short period of time (usually under a year or 6 months). This might be an arrangement that doesn't have to go through the court, but is through a private agreement.

Title: Options around Life-Sustaining Treatments
Definition: This category covers issues when a person needs life-sustaining medical treatment to stay alive, and there may be questions about whether these treatments should be withheld (not provided in the first place), or withdrawn (ended after they have begun).

Title: State and Local Medical assistance programs
Definition: This category covers options from a local state, city, county, or municipality to help cover the costs of medical care. This includes medical programs that are run by local governments directly, or local government-funded assistance programs to help cover people's costs of care.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1592200], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1592600], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [57]

Title: Medicaid health coverage
Definition: This category covers the Medicaid government program that provides people with limited income access to health care. It covers who qualifies in each state for Medicaid based on income or other conditions (pregnancy, elderly, disability, children, etc). it also covers issues of what types of issues or treatments that Medicaid covers, what happens if there are payment issues, and how program enrollment might be terminated.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1510100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1510099], Legal Server Index Taxonomy [LS002-00051], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1510100], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [51]

Title: Medicare health coverage
Definition: This category covers the Medicare health insurance program run by the government, that covers people 65 and over, some people with disability status, and some people with end-stage renal or ALS/Lou Gehrig's disease. This category covers who is eligible for Medicare coverage, how to apply for it, dealing with payment issues, what is covered by it, the different Parts A, B, C, and D, and how one's enrollment might be terminated.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1520100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1520099], Legal Server Index Taxonomy [LS002-00052], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [52]

Title: Contesting a will
Definition: This category covers issues when a person would like to challenge a written will and testament, about how a now-deceased person's property is divided up. This includes who is eligible to contest a will through a legal process, what this process entails, what kinds of objections are valid, and what might happen after the contesting process ends.

Title: Dying without a will (intestate)
Definition: This category covers the law and procedure of what happens to a person's estate if they die without a will. This is called dying "intestate". This covers the local state laws that determine who will get the person's property (including money, securities, real estate, and other assets), what family and partner relationships affect this division, and what happens if there is a probate court process to administer this division.

Title: Probate process for an uncontested will
Definition: This category covers what happens when a person dies with a will, and then the will goes through the court probate process -- without anyone objecting to the will or raising any challenges to it.

Title: Going to Probate Court
Definition: This category concerns what Probate Court is, how they make decisions about whether a will is valid, how people are notified that an estate is being decided in the probate process, how possible beneficiaries can raise issues, how the court appoints people to administer the process, and how final decisions are made.

Title: When an estate can avoid probate
Definition: This category covers the options people might have to have a now-deceased person's estate may be considered a "small estate" so that it does not have to go through a formal court probate process. This might be through a legal document like an affidavit, if the estate's value is underneath a certain amount and if real estate will not be transferred. These rules differ by state.

Title: Drafting and signing a will
Definition: This category covers how a person can create a will that will be considered valid after they die, in order to specify what will happen to their property and responsibilities.

Title: Updating a Will through a Codicil
Definition: This category covers an option for a person to update a will they already wrote, by using a supplementary document called a 'codicil'. This can be to change who will receive property, who the executor will be, who will be guardian for children, or other decisions that were in the original will. The document would be used to change the will without revoking the original. This category covers what makes a codicil valid, how it can be drafted, how it can be signed and verified, and how it may be used after death.

Title: Being a 'beneficiary' to another's estate
Definition: This category covers what rights, options, and responsibilities a person has if they have 'beneficiary' status for another now-deceased person's estate. This includes the right to be informed about the will, other beneficiaries, raise issues, receive their inheritance, and be updated about the execution of the will/probate process.

Title: Distributing money through Payable-on-Death account
Definition: This category covers how a person might have other people directly receive money after they die, through a bank account called a Payable-on-Death (PDA) Account. It covers how to set such an account up, how long it will take people to receive money after you die, if and how the fund will be frozen, and how this account works with a probate court process.

Title: Estate Planning for a beneficiary with a disability
Definition: This category covers issues that a person might face when drafting their estate plans, if one of their children or other beneficiaries have disabilities. This includes how to transfer assets in ways that do not harm that beneficiary's ability to receive public benefits and other support. It also includes how to ensure that the beneficiary will have long-term support for health and care costs.

Title: State housing assistance programs
Definition: This category covers state programs that might help a person with housing costs on an emergency, temporary basis -- like for rent, utilities, and other costs.

Title: Remedies for discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers what an employee (or potential employee) might be eligible to receive if they have faced discrimination in their employment. This includes options to get back pay, compensatory damages, or punitive damages for the discrimination they have faced.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1210600], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1210699]

Title: Getting Back-Pay after discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers whether and how an employee can get back-pay after they have faced discrimination at work. This would be for the salary or other payments they would have received, had they not gone through the discrimination.

Title: Getting Compensated after discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers an employee's options to get paid for compensatory damages for the discrimination they have experienced at work. Compensatory damages cover the costs the person has had to pay out-of-pocket because of the discrimination. This might include job search costs, medical expenses, emotional harms, inconvenience, mental anguish, or loss of enjoyment of life.

Title: Punitive damages for work discrimination
Definition: This category covers if and how an employee can get punitive damages against an employer for discrimination. Punitive damages are generally possible if the employer's discrimination was especially malicious or reckless. This category covers how much money a person could get, what limits there are on this money, and when punitive damages might be possible.

Title: Getting Worker's Compensation benefits
Definition: This category covers if and how an employee can get Worker's Compensation benefits. The laws vary state to state, but generally workers who are injured on the job or have a sickness or disability that is made worse by workplace conditions can access workers' compensation to help them cover their costs. This also covers whether Worker's Compensation programs stop an employee from being able to sue their employer for their injury.

Title: Working conditions that are unsafe or unhealthy
Definition: This category covers an employee's options if they are working in a place that seems to have health or safety hazards. This could be for dangerous machines, toxic chemicals, or poor training. This category includes the ability to file complaints with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), to get the workplace inspected and improved. It also covers what happens if an employee faces retaliation for making a complaint.

Title: Being drug tested when applying for a job
Definition: This category covers a job applicant's rights and options if a potential employer is asking them to take a drug or alcohol test as part of the application process. This includes options to refuse a drug test, what rights you have if you fail the drug test, and what rules the employer must follow to correctly do drug testing without discrimination or inaccuracies.

Title: Being tested for drugs or alcohol at work
Definition: This category covers an employee's rights and options if an employer is asking them to take a drug or alcohol test as part of their job. This includes options to refuse a drug test, what rights you have if you fail the drug test, and what rules the employer must follow to correctly do drug testing without discrimination or inaccuracies. It also includes an employee's ability to challenge a drug test, and when employers are allowed to require a test based on 'reasonable suspicion'.

Title: Wage payment, hours, and breaks at work
Definition: This category covers issues an employee may have with how much they are getting paid, if they are getting adequate overtime, if employers are requiring workers to clock out during breaks, if the employer is paying less than the minimum wage, or if there are other claims/problems around the amount paid for the hours worked. This might include topics like 'wage theft', when workers are not being paid what is owed to them.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1220100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1220199], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [22], Legal Server Index Taxonomy [LS002-00022]

Title: Minimum wage at work
Definition: This category covers issues an employee might have if they think an employer is not paying them the required minimum wage in their state or local area. It also covers situations when an employer may pay less than the minimum wage because employees make tips -- with issues around whether this is legal and how to challenge this practice if the employee believes they are not getting paid enough.

Title: Being paid a 'prevailing wage'
Definition: This category covers what rights certain kinds of employees have to make a set 'prevailing wage' for workers in their industry and position. This applies particularly when a worker is on a project funded by government money, like a construction project. This category covers if an employer has to pay certain workers a prevailing wage, how a worker can complain about it, and what compensation or other rights they have.

Title: Getting paid for overtime work
Definition: This category covers issues that an employee has about getting paid enough for overtime work. This includes what kinds of workers qualify for overtime pay, how much they should get, and what to do if you have not been paid fairly.

Title: Meal and Rest Breaks
Definition: This category covers what employees rights are for getting breaks to eat and rest, and whether they will be paid for the time they are on the break. This includes whether employees have to clock out at breaks, if your state requires employers to give rest or lunch breaks, and how much you should be paid for them.

Title: Getting paid for trainings and work-related activities
Definition: This category covers issues a worker might have, about whether they should be getting paid for activities related to work, like required training, travel, seminars, waiting periods, on-call periods, sleep time, and other activities that might be involved with employment but not the work that the worker typically does on their job.

Title: Getting reimbursed for work-related costs
Definition: This category covers questions about getting paid back by their employer for money they spent on work-related costs, like uniforms, supplies, or other materials.

Title: Employer interfering with union activity (Unfair Labor Practices)
Definition: This category covers protections and issues for employees who are facing interference by their employer, when trying to organize, join, or assist a union. It also covers what kinds of employee activities are protected as concerted activities, like conversations, posting on social media, or collective bargaining. This is in part defined by the National Labor Relations Act, and other labor laws, that lay out protections for employees and unions.

Title: Unfair Labor Practices by Unions
Definition: This category covers restrictions on what unions can do at a workplace, under laws around unfair labor practices. This includes situations when unions may be restraining or coercing employees regarding their choice not to support a union, crossing a picket line, restraining an employer's choice of bargaining representative, causing employers to penalize employees who engage in anti-union activities, or charging excessive fees. This category covers how an employee might make a complaint to the NLRB about these practices, and what rights they have.

Title: Being fired after whistleblowing
Definition: This category covers options and rights for a person who has been terminated from their job after being a whistleblower regarding illegal activity by their employer. This includes when whistleblowers have protections against termination, retaliation, or ability to make claims to be compensated for being fired.

Title: Being fired from a job
Definition: This category covers issues a person might have after they have been terminated from their job. It includes the possibility to raise a 'wrongful termination' claim, when employers are allowed to let a worker go, what reasons are acceptable for it, and what a worker can do if they think they have been fired illegally or in a way that is against public policy (like for retaliation or discrimination).
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1291500], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1291599]

Title: Minors' protections and restrictions at work
Definition: This category covers the legal limits on the employment of minors (people under the age of 18). This includes whether the minors can be employed at all, what jobs are considered too hazardous to have minors employed, what limits on hours or activities there might be, and what extra protections they might have at work.

Title: Being an Employee vs. an Independent Contractor
Definition: This category covers questions a worker might have about their relationship with the organization they're working for, including if you have been misclassified as an independent contractor rather than an employee.

Title: Mismanagement of retirement and pension plans (under ERISA)
Definition: This category covers what employees can do if they believe that their employer has violated their obligations to properly manage retirement, pension, and profit-sharing plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA). This includes obligations to provide benefits to current or former employees, to maintain their fiduciary duties toward the employees, and to protect their rights.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1250300], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1250220]

Title: Eligibility for pension plan or retirement benefits
Definition: This category covers questions around whether a person is eligible to join a pension plan or get retirement benefits through their work.

Title: Vesting of retirement plan
Definition: This category covers issues around when an employee's retirement plans vest, meaning that they have ownership over the account balance that the employer cannot take away. This includes rules around losing retirement benefits if a person leaves the job or works less than a certain number of hours. It also includes rules around when there must e 100% vesting.

Title: Railroad workers' retirement system
Definition: This category covers issues around railroad retirement benefits. This is typically eligible to railroad workers and their families through the federal agency Railroad Retirement Board. This category covers eligibility, overpayments, benefit appeals, and other resources.

Title: Sexual harassment at work
Definition: This category covers situations when a person is facing sexual harassment at work or an interview for employment, including propositions, jokes, touching, and other physical or verbal conduct that is sexual in nature. This category includes the standards of what constitutes sexual harassment, how to make complaints, what workers' or applicants' rights are, and steps they can take to protect themselves.

Title: Affirmative Action for employment
Definition: This category covers if and whether affirmative action policies will affect a person who is applying for a job. It covers the rules that might determine if an employer can or should promote job opportunities for specific groups of people, like people of color, women, people with disabilities, or military veterans.

Title: Age discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers options and rights for a person who may be facing inappropriate treatment at work (or potential work) based on their age. This includes around their hiring, firing, pay, job assignments, promotions, or comments and insults. The category covers what the standards for discrimination are, and what a person can do to protect themselves.

Title: Disability discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers options and rights for a person who may be facing inappropriate treatment at work (or potential work) based on their disability. This includes around their hiring, firing, pay, job assignments, promotions, or comments and insults. The category covers what the standards for discrimination are, and what a person can do to protect themselves.

Title: Gender discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers options and rights for a person who may be facing inappropriate treatment at work (or potential work) based on their gender. This includes around their hiring, firing, pay, job assignments, promotions, or comments and insults. The category covers what the standards for discrimination are, and what a person can do to protect themselves.

Title: Racial Justice and discrimination
Definition: This category covers rights and options for people facing discrimination, harassment, unequal treatment, and other disproportionate harm based on their race.

Title: Racial and Ethnic discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers options and rights for a person who may be facing inappropriate treatment at work (or potential work) based on their race, ethnicity, or country of origin. This includes around their hiring, firing, pay, job assignments, promotions, or comments and insults. The category covers what the standards for discrimination are, and what a person can do to protect themselves.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1210502], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1210501]

Title: Religious discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers options and rights for a person who may be facing inappropriate treatment at work (or potential work) based on their religion. This includes around their hiring, firing, pay, job assignments, promotions, or comments and insults. The category covers what the standards for discrimination are, and what a person can do to protect themselves.

Title: Sexual orientation or Gender Identity discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers options and rights for a person who may be facing inappropriate treatment at work (or potential work) based on their sexual orientation (real or perceived) or their gender identity. This includes around their hiring, firing, pay, job assignments, promotions, or comments and insults. The category covers what the standards for discrimination are, and what a person can do to protect themselves.

Title: Martial or Parental Status discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers options and rights for a person who may be facing inappropriate treatment at work (or potential work) based on their family status -- like around having children, being married, single, divorced, widowed, or head of household. This includes around their hiring, firing, pay, job assignments, promotions, or comments and insults. The category covers what the standards for discrimination are, and what a person can do to protect themselves.

Title: Proving discrimination at work
Definition: This category covers the legal standards and types of behavior that apply when a worker is bringing a complaint of discrimination against an employer.

Title: Discrimination based on a 'bona fide occupational qualification'
Definition: This category covers when an employer might have a legitimate reason to discriminate against workers or applicants, based on a 'bona fide occupational qualification' that is related to the work. (This does not usually allow them to discriminate based on race). Often employers use this standard to defend themselves, to say that they had to discriminate based on safety or other important concerns.

Title: Neutral work policies that lead to discrimination (disparate impact)
Definition: This category covers situations when an employer has a policy that seems neutral on its face (like a certain test, requirement, or procedure) that leads to discrimination against workers of a certain race, gender, age, religion, or another protected demographic group. This category covers what someone needs to show to prove 'disparate impact' discrimination, and how employers can defend themselves.

Title: Agricultural workers' protections
Definition: This category covers what rights and special protections agricultural (farm) workers have -- especially under the special federal laws like the Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act (MSPA). These include obligations that employers have around labor standards and communication, as well as what workers and contractors must do in terms of registering with the US Department of Labor.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1260100], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [26]

Title: Health care coverage through employer
Definition: This category covers workers' rights and protections to get health care coverage through their employer -- like whether employers must provide health insurance, whether dependents would be covered, how COBRA works, and what happens when one is terminated or leaves their job.

Title: COBRA health insurance post-employement
Definition: This category covers issues a person might have with employment-based health care coverage after they have left a job or has been terminated -- or when they (or their family members) would otherwise have their health coverage end. This includes who is eligible to receive COBRA insurance coverage, how long it lasts, and what it covers. It also includes how to raise complaints if the employer doesn't offer COBRA coverage.

Title: Making a complaint under the Fair Labor Standards Act
Definition: This category covers employees' possible options to raise a complaint against their employer for a violation of how much they are paid, whether they are getting overtime, or other possible violation of the Fair Labor Standards Act. This includes what kind of employee is eligible for protections under this Act, which employers must abide by its rules, and how to raise a claim about a violation.

Title: Employment records from former job
Definition: This category covers how a person might request their personnel file from a former employer, how other possible employers might request your past employment records, and deal with other issues about what a previous employer says or releases about your work history.

Title: Being a subcontractor
Definition: This category covers the rights, obligations, and duties of subcontractor workers, who work for 'general contractors' at a job. This includes what obligations the employer and the general contractor have toward them, what tax and contract obligations subcontractors have, and what protections they have regarding wages, breaks, working conditions, termination, and other situations.

Title: Taking leave for family and medical reasons
Definition: This category covers employees' options for taking family and medical Leave (especially under the Family and Medical Leave Act), including for giving birth, caring for a child, caring for another family member, dealing with an illness or other issues. This category covers questions about which employees are eligible for taking leave, if they will be paid, if they can be fired, how to get approved for leave, and what happens if you think your employer has violated their obligations.

Title: Poultry workers' protections
Definition: This category covers issues and rights for those who work in the poultry industry specifically.

Title: Racial and ethnic discrimination in agricultural work
Definition: This category covers the discrimination potentially faced by people working in agriculture based on their race or ethnicity, including what protections and rights they have.

Title: Suing an employer for a tort
Definition: This category covers options for a person to sue an employer while working there or after leaving their job. It might be for tort claims for negligence around a safe workplace, fraud (when an employer deceives them), defamation (when an employer lies about them), false imprisonment (for not allowing them to leave), or for assault and battery (for allowing them to be injured on the job).

Title: Wrongful termination of employees who are not 'at will'
Definition: This category covers employees who are not the usual 'at will' employees (who can be fired at any time), who can raise a claim if they are fired. This might be based on public policy, anti-discrimination, implied contracts of good faith and fair dealing, or other protections that an employer has against termination.

Title: Building good credit
Definition: This category is about strategies and options a person can use to build credit that can help them access more lending opportunities and other resources.

Title: Repairing credit
Definition: This category is about how a person can improve their credit and credit report if they have problems they need to address.

Title: Finding and understanding a credit report
Definition: This category covers how a person can find, understand, and deal with their credit report.

Title: Accessing credit and borrowing money
Definition: This category covers issues that consumers may have in borrowing money and accessing credit. This could be regarding 'credit invisibles' (consumers who do not have credit records or scores).

Title: Building Contractors and Construction problems
Definition: This category covers issues that a consumer might have with shoddy construction work, incomplete construction, or other issues with a contractor's work or representations about what work they would do. This could include fraud by the contractor.

Title: Consumer Fraud and Misrepresentation
Definition: This category covers issues that a consumer may have after the purchase of a product or service, around possible lies or exaggerations about the purchase, and damages that are caused by it.

Title: Installment Contracts
Definition: This category concerns when a person buys a product or service when the payment or the delivery happens in a series instead of all at once. This might be for cards, land, technology, farming equipment, or retail sales. Issues might be around the contract's details, failure to perform, or enforcing it.

Title: Installment Purchases and Rent-to-Own
Definition: This category covers issues consumers might have when buying things through installment payment plans, around repayment, getting out of debt, credit insurance, or other issues.

Title: Telemarketers
Definition: This category covers consumers' rights and options when dealing with telemarketers over phone or text messages.

Title: Door-to-Door Sales
Definition: This category covers issues with salespeople who come to homes to sell things, including possible fraud, the ability to stop them from visiting, abuses, and other problems.

Title: Spam on Email or Text
Definition: This category concerns a person's problem with receiving spam messages over email or text message, including fraud and scams, how to stop unwanted messages, and other issues.

Title: Using Bank Accounts
Definition: This category covers issues a person might have in getting and maintaining a bank account. This can be around understanding the options and rules of using banks, and how to maintain a bank account.

Title: Using Checks
Definition: This category covers issues around a person using checks for their finances, including how to write them, how they work, and what might go wrong.

Title: Using Debit Cards
Definition: This category covers how a person can use debit cards for their finances, including how to get a card, what fees and penalties there might be, and how the card transactions and payments work.

Title: Using Credit Cards
Definition: This category covers consumers' issues with getting and using credit cards, or other forms of credit. This includes literacy around how credit works, what consequences there are, and how to maintain and use their credit card.

Title: Financial Identity Theft
Definition: This category covers problems when a person's information is used by another person to make purchases, get credit cards, rent a home, or get utilities. It also might be for stealing tax refunds, or using checks from the bank account.

Title: Criminal Identity Theft with police
Definition: This issue concerns what a person can do if their identity has been stolen by a person after they have committed a crime, and have presented themselves to the police with a false identity.

Title: Homeowner's Insurance
Definition: This category covers issues that a homeowner might have with insuring their home, including getting covered by an insurance policy, making claims, dealing with scams or frauds, ending coverage, etc.

Title: Renters' Insurance
Definition: This category covers a tenant's options to get rental insurance for their home or property they're renting, how to make claims, how to deal with problems or fraud, and how to end coverage.

Title: Insurance Scams and Fraud
Definition: This category covers options a person might have if they think they may be scammed around an insurance policy, or if they have been accused of insurance fraud. This could be by an insurance company that has deceived the consumer, or if the consumer may be misrepresenting their situation.

Title: Life Insurance
Definition: This category covers how a person might get, change, use, or end a life insurance policy. It also might cover how a survivor (like a spouse or child) may make claims of the insurance funds after the death.

Title: Service Members' Group Life Insurance
Definition: This category covers options for veterans and military service members to get covered with group life insurance policies, and how their survivors may make use of them upon death.

Title: Benefits for service members after death
Definition: This category covers what financial and other benefits that a service members' family can expect after the death of the service member, and how to make use of these benefits or deal with any problems.

Title: Disability Insurance coverage
