Definition: This category covers how a person who is dealing with a disability can get insurance coverage for financial support, including through their employer. This could cover injuries, illnesses, pregnancies, and other situations when a person cannot earn a living and needs financial support. This could be about how to get insurance, how to make claims, how to dispute denials, and how long the coverage lasts.

Title: Speeding and Moving Violations
Definition: This category covers a person's options if they are facing a ticket for speeding, running a red light, or other problem with their driving.

Title: License and Registration Traffic Tickets
Definition: This category covers issues a person might have when they have gotten a ticket for issues with their driver's license or registration.

Title: No Insurance Traffic Tickets
Definition: This category covers issues a person might have if they have a ticket for driving without insurance, or driving without proof of insurance.

Title: Parking Tickets
Definition: This category covers issues a person might have for a parking ticket, around how their car was parked.

Title: Driving Under the Influence
Definition: This category covers options and rights for a person who is charged with driving under the influence (DUI), and what consequences they may face.

Title: Going to Traffic Court
Definition: This category covers how a person can go to traffic court to respond to a ticket, contest it, or see what options are available to resolve it.

Title: Driver's License Suspension
Definition: This category covers how a person might have their driver's license suspended or taken away, how to contest this, and how to deal with the suspension. This could cover suspensions for traffic tickets, or for deteriorating health or ability to drive.

Title: Reinstating a Driver's License
Definition: This category covers how a person can have their driver's license reinstated after

Title: Predatory Lending
Definition: This category covers situations when a person may be targeted with loan offers that are abusive, fraudulent, or discriminatory.
Taxonomies: Legal Server Index Taxonomy [LS002-00005], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1060300], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [05]

Title: Student Loans and Financial Aid
Definition: This category covers issues a person may have when trying to borrow money to pay for school, like around getting financial aid, taking out student loans, paying them back, and dealing with any concerns. This may include how to resolve student loans, understanding aid's conditions, and dealing with possible predatory or fraudulent practices.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1160100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1160199], Legal Server Index Taxonomy [LS002-00016], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [16]

Title: Student Loan Discharge or Cancellation
Definition: This category covers when people's loans for education may be discharged (or canceled, so the person doesn't have to pay them back). This includes what situations may result in discharge, like for disability, bankruptcy, closed schools, identity theft, or school fraud.

Title: Student Loan Forgiveness
Definition: This category covers a person's options to possibly have their student loans forgiven, including options to do public service or work out a payment plan to lessen the amount of the loan they have to pay back.

Title: Student Loan Default and Delinquency
Definition: This category covers what happens if a person defaults, or doesn't pay back, their student loans. This includes the consequences of default, possible defenses and protections a person might use if they don't pay back on time or don't pay it in full.

Title: Student Loan Fraud
Definition: This category covers situations when a person feels they may have been scammed by a student loan provider, a school, or by family members around student loans. This includes issues around identity theft, predatory lending, or other fraud.

Title: Payday loans
Definition: This category covers options when a person is dealing with short-term, payday loans, which are typically smaller loans with very high fees or interest. This might include issues of falling behind on the loan, overdrafting bank accounts, illegal payday loan companies and practices, or other issues.

Title: Understanding the terms of a loan or credit card
Definition: This category covers situations when a person is trying to understand the terms of the loan or credit card a person is considering or has taken out, including what obligations a company has under the Truth in Lending Act, and what a person can do if the terms aren't clearly communicated.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1060500], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1060599], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1060501]

Title: Canceling (or rescission of) a loan
Definition: This category covers consumers' possible right of rescission to cancel a loan or line of credit. This covers when people have this right, how to use it, and what it gives a person.

Title: Fees and Finance Charges for a loan
Definition: This category covers issues when a person has taken out consumer credit or borrowed money, and is dealing with fees or interest (finance charges) for this borrowing. It includes consumers' rights to know about these charges, how to respond if they seem overly high, or to complain if there has been possible fraud or miscommunication.

Title: High interest rates and Usury protections
Definition: This category covers issues around high-interest rates on loans and consumer credit, and when a person might be protected by laws that set limits on how much interest can be charged.

Title: False advertising, deceptive pricing, and unfair trade
Definition: This category covers consumers' possible protections against unfair and deceptive trade practices, like around when a company may misrepresent what it is selling, what the price is, what guarantees there are, extra fees, or other unfair trade practices.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1080100], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [08], Legal Server Index Taxonomy [LS002-00008]

Title: Hearings challenging public benefits decisions
Definition: This category covers what a person can expect if they must go to a hearing with an administrative agency about their health care and human services benefits (like SNAP, TANF, Medicare, Medicaid, general assistance, or otherwise), including how the hearing will work, what to bring, and what outcomes may result.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2023510], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2023520]

Title: Hearing for labor issues and unemployment claims
Definition: This category covers what a person can expect if they must go to a hearing with an administrative agency about their labor or employment benefits or claims, including how the hearing will work, what to bring, and what outcomes may result.

Title: Hearing with Social Security Administration
Definition: This category covers what a person can expect if they must go to a hearing with an administrative agency about Social Security Administration benefits, including how the hearing will work, what to bring, and what outcomes may result.

Title: Alternative Dispute Resolution, Mediation, and Settlements
Definition: This category covers how a person, involved in a lawsuit or potential lawsuit, may use more collaborative services to reach a settlement with the other side outside of a court trial -- like in the form of an Alternative Dispute Resolution service, a mediator, a diversion program, or another process that avoids a trial.

Title: Appealing a court's judgment
Definition: This category covers situations when a person thinks the court has ruled incorrectly in their case, and they appeal the ruling. This covers how to make an appeal, respond to an appeal from the other side, and deal with the procedure.

Title: Court's ability to hear, refuse, or move a case
Definition: This category covers situations when a person tries to bring a lawsuit in a court, and the court's decision and rationale about whether to hear or refuse the case. This could be based on issues like jurisdiction, whether there is a case and question, whether the issue has already been resolved, or other issues.

Title: Having a free lawyer appointed
Definition: This category covers a person's options or rights to have a free lawyer appointed to help them with their legal problem. People facing most criminal charges have a right to a lawyer appointed to represent them for free, and some in civil cases may have a right for a lawyer.

Title: Standards for reviewing an appeal
Definition: This category covers the legal standard that will help decide whether a person's appeal of a court's ruling will be accepted or rejected. This includes the 'arbitrary and capricious' standard, that would let a higher court reject a lower court's ruling if it was incorrect or abused discretion.

Title: Judge's powers and behavior
Definition: This category covers issues with how judges behave and make decisions during a trial. This could include possible problems like bias, or their powers to use their discretion and make decisions or issue penalities.

Title: Class Action lawsuits
Definition: This category covers how a person may bring or participate in a class action lawsuit, where a group of people all challenge the same party or issue together.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2020600], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2020699]

Title: Getting a class action certified
Definition: This category covers how a class action is accepted to become 'certified' -- in which a court agrees that a class action is the best way to decide on multiple people's claims.

Title: Defining a class in a class action
Definition: This category covers how a 'class' is defined in a possible class action lawsuit.

Title: Judgments, Settlements, and Appeals of court cases
Definition: This category covers the various ways a lawsuit or criminal case can end, in terms of how courts may make rulings, accept the parties' settlement agreements, or deal with appeals of the case.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2021700], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2021799]

Title: Consent Decrees or Settlements of a case
Definition: This category covers how a court case might end with a decree or settlement that resolves the dispute without the court finding liability or guilt -- and instead allows the plaintiff and defendant to finish the case with an agreement and plan between them.

Title: Default Judgment against one party
Definition: This category covers one way that a court case can end -- a default judgment -- after the plaintiff or defendant fail to take a required action in the case. This often is when a defendant doesn't reply to the lawsuit summons or doesn't appear at a court hearing. This covers what a party might do after the default judgment has been entered, what they can do to overturn it, or how to request it.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2021701], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1770402]

Title: Enforcing a court's judgment
Definition: This category covers how one party, who had a ruling in their favor by the court, can try to enforce this ruling -- by possibly getting money or other damages from the other party.

Title: Declaratory judgment about a case
Definition: This category covers one type of judgment a court might make about a situation, a declaratory judgment, that does not provide an enforceable ruling but that states what the court's findings on parties' rights and relationships are.

Title: Enforcing a judgment in another jurisdiction
Definition: This category covers the obligations of one jurisdiction (like a state) to enforce the rulings from a court in another. This could be under the Full Faith and Credit Clause.

Title: Contempt for not following a judgment
Definition: This category covers situations when a court has made a judgment, but one of the parties has not followed it -- and the other wants to have them found in 'contempt'. This covers how the party can file a complaint for contempt, how the court decides on it, and what the consequences are for being found to be in contempt.

Title: Court costs and fees
Definition: This category covers issues around how much it costs to go to court (like with filing fees for a lawsuit), and how people may pay or argue for others to have to pay these costs.

Title: Claiming Money (Damages) in a lawsuit
Definition: This category covers how a person can claim 'damages', or money compensation, for a harm that another person or group has done. This includes figuring out how much money to ask for, how to prove it, and what outcomes may result.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2034100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2022303]

Title: Processing Delays by an administrative agency
Definition: This category covers issues around delays in how an administrative agency responds to a request, claim, application, or other process. This could include delays in processing immigration applications or benefits requests.

Title: Discovery process to get evidence from other side
Definition: This category covers the formal process of Discovery before a trial, in which each party can request the other to give evidence to them about the case -- like through depositions, interrogatories, request for documents, subpoenas, and motions to compel evidence.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2021000], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2021099]

Title: Depositions of witnesses
Definition: This category covers how a party in a court case can get evidence from witnesses before a trial, through a deposition interview. Depositions result in witnesses under oath giving testimony that could be used at trial.

Title: Expert witness discovery before a trial
Definition: This category covers how parties in a lawsuit might use discovery process before a trial to gather evidence around expert witnesses, including disclosing their identity, what they can be asked about and what the other party needs to know.

Title: Extending time for discovery process
Definition: This category covers how a party can extend the timeline of the discovery process, by requesting extra time to file or to serve evidence requests.

Title: Interrogatory request during discovery
Definition: This category covers how a party in a lawsuit may get evidence from the other side during the discovery period before trial, using a list of questions called an interrogatory.

Title: Non-compliance with Discovery rules
Definition: This category covers what happens when one party in a lawsuit doesn't follow the rules and process of Discovery to get evidence before a trial.

Title: Privileged information protected from Discovery
Definition: This category covers what information is privileged, and so does not have to be shared during the discovery process. This could be information like that from a confidential relationship like attorney-client, doctor-patient, or others.

Title: Turning over documents during Discovery
Definition: This category covers how one party in the lawsuit may request the other to produce, or turn over, documents with evidence related to the case before the trial begins.

Title: Sanctions for discovery violations
Definition: This category covers penalties that a court might impose on a party in a lawsuit for not following discovery process. This could be money sanctions or otherwise.

Title: Bias by a judge
Definition: This category covers situations when a person believes the court or the judge who is working on their case may be biased against them. This covers how to raise objections about the impartiality of the judge or court officer.

Title: Judge's discretion in a case
Definition: This category covers issues and rules of when a judge can make a decision or ruling in a case based on their individual discretion -- and when they may cross a line into arbitrary or unequal decisions.

Title: Estoppel to stop an issue being raised again
Definition: This category covers situations when a party may try to raise an issue on a matter that has already been decided on in the court. This is known as Estoppel, to stop an issue from being raised again when something has already been established.

Title: Due Process rights when dealing with the government
Definition: This category covers what a person's rights are to have "due process" that lets them protect their interests before government agents can deprive them of life, liberty, or property. This could include process that they have a right to when dealing with courts, police, prosecutors and other government agents. This includes for civil matters, criminal matters, and administrative agency matters.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2024200], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1850100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1850199], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1850103]

Title: Due Process rights in an administrative agency hearing
Definition: This category covers rights that a person has when trying to raise a claim or appeal a decision with an administrative agency, like around their benefits or services. This includes due process rights for TANF and public benefits decisions.

Title: Court Abstaining from hearing a case
Definition: This covers situations when a court may 'abstain' from hearing a case, because they decide that the issue is better addressed by another court. For example, a federal court may abstain from a case in order that a state court decide the legal issue.

Title: Immunity from lawsuits or prosecution
Definition: This category covers situations when a person or organization may be protected from lawsuits or criminal charges, so that they cannot be brought to trial because of this immunity.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2021400], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2021499]

Title: Government's Sovereign Immunity from lawsuits
Definition: This category covers when government agencies or employees may have protection from lawsuits, based on their 'sovereign immunity'. This covers when a person may bring a lawsuit against a state worker or agency, and what legal standards courts will use to decide whether to hear the case or not.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2021402], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2320130]

Title: Government officials' Qualified Immunity from lawsuits
Definition: This category covers situations when a person may try to sue a government official, and that official may have qualified (limited) immunity from the lawsuits if they are frivolous or the official acted in good faith. This might be related to police officers who may face lawsuits for their treatment of people.  It might be related to civil rights cases, in which a person sues state officials for violating their rights.

Title: In Forma Pauperis court fee waivers
Definition: This category covers options for people to file lawsuits and participate in courts without having to pay court fees, if they can show their financial need.

Title: Juries
Definition: This category covers how juries work, when they are available, how they are selected, and what they are allowed to do and not do.

Title: Court's Jurisdiction to hear a case
Definition: This category covers whether a court is able to hear a case, based on whether it has jurisdiction over the people involved or the issue in dispute.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2021800], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2021899]

Title: Court's decision whether there is a case and controversy
Definition: This category covers issues about whether a court will hear a case, depending on whether there is a 'justiciable' controversy between parties about their legal rights that is still in conflict -- and that is not 'moot' or over.

Title: Court's jurisdiction when parties come from different states
Definition: This category covers issues when parties in the lawsuit are from different states or countries, and the courts must decide what court has jurisdiction -- including if there is a diversity of citizenship that would allow the case to be removed from state court to federal court.

Title: Litigant's exhaustion of remedies in original court
Definition: This category covers situations where a litigant may want to bring a claim in a new court, but the court refuses to hear their case until they have gone through all remedies in the original court they had the case in. This relates to situations when a person may have a case in an administrative agency or state court body, and their ability to go to a federal court or other court.

Title: Federal court's jurisdiction to hear federal questions
Definition: This category covers issues around whether a federal or state court should hear a certain legal case, based on whether the question of law or violation regards federal law (the US Constitution or federal law) or not.

Title: Federal court's ability to hear a state law question
Definition: This category covers issues when a federal court might be able to hear a claim that it otherwise wouldn't have jurisdiction over, based on a situation when a claim arises out of the same incident that the court is already hearing. This is sometimes called 'pendent jurisdiction'.

Title: Court's personal jurisdiction over parties
Definition: This category covers issues about whether a court has the ability to hear a case involving a person or organization, based on where they are located or whether they have contacts with this court's jurisdiction. This is called 'personal jurisdiction' -- that regards whether a court has the authority to decide claims about this party if they aren't located in the same jurisdiction.

Title: Appealing a judge's ruling through Mandamus
Definition: This category covers situations when a party may want to appeal a judge's decision but is blocked by procedural rules, and so may try to file a writ of mandamus to compel the judge to change their decision.

Title: Court's decision whether a case is moot
Definition: This category covers issues around a case's possible 'mootness', in which a court may decide that a legal action can't be brought because there is not a live dispute to be resolved.

Title: Agencies not following court decisions (Nonacquiescence)
Definition: This category covers situations in which a federal agency practices nonacquiescence, like when they do not follow the decisions of court rulings that affect them.

Title: Filing and Serving pleadings, forms, and court paperwork
Definition: This category covers issues around how a person can file 'pleadings' paperwork and forms with the court, that explain their position to the court and the other side. This could include complaints, petitions, bills, answers, counterclaims, or other papers that explain their dispute and claims.

Title: Suing to enforce a law (Private right of action)
Definition: This category covers situations when a person might want to enforce a law or legal requirement. They may try to use a private right of action to bring a lawsuit to enforce the law.

Title: Seeking an injunction to compel an action
Definition: This category covers how a person might sue another party for 'injunctive relief', in which they want that party to do certain acts or behave in a certain way. This is one remedy that could be claimed along with money damages.

Title: Seeking a preliminary injunction before a trial ends
Definition: This category covers situations when a person may want to get an injunction, or a court order to have the other act in a certain way, before a trial has ended (or even before the case has gone to trial).

Title: Outcomes a plaintiff can seek in a lawsuit
Definition: This category covers what a person can try to get a court order for, in a civil lawsuit against another party. This may be called remedies. It could include money damages, injunctions, or other things for the court to order.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2022300], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2022399]

Title: Removing a case from state to federal court
Definition: This category covers 'removal jurisdiction' in which a party in the lawsuit tries to have a civil lawsuit from a state court to a federal court.

Title: Res Judicata to stop a claim being raised again
Definition: This category covers situations when a party in a lawsuit thinks that a claim has already been settled in court, and so should not be able to be raised again in court. This can be called res judicata or claim preclusion.

Title: Court's decision whether a case is ripe
Definition: This category covers situations when one party might be raising a claim, and the court decides whether the case is 'ripe' -- meaning that the situation actually has a substantial controversy and that it is not a hypothetical question or possibility.

Title: Proposing a rules change for an administrative agency
Definition: This category covers the process and options for a government agency that is proposing a change in how it functions and what rules guide it. This includes how a proposal is made, how people can comment on it, and how comments may be integrated into the proposal.

Title: Notices and Public Comment on proposed government rules
Definition: This category covers how people might get notice that a government agency is proposing a new rule, and how it may give notice to the public about the rule and analysis of it.

Title: Serving court papers on other party
Definition: This category covers the rules and options for getting paperwork about a lawsuit or court matter, to one of the parties. This could be called 'service of process', and may involve serving complaints, writs, summons, or other court orders and papers to ensure that the other person is aware of them.

Title: Standards of review for appealed cases
Definition: This category covers how higher courts might review an appeal of a previous court case. This might be called 'standards of review', that sets out whether courts might review an appeal on questions of law, questions of fact, or matters of discretion. This category covers reasons that a case might be accepted for appeal, and what the higher court will be evaluating on the appeal.

Title: Standing of a person to bring a lawsuit
Definition: This category covers situations where there is a question about whether a person has 'standing' to bring a lawsuit to the court. This can apply to situations in which a person needs to show that they have actually suffered harm or injury, or that they will be.

Title: Rules of civil procedure
Definition: This category covers the formal rules in state or federal law, about how parties and cases proceed through the court.

Title: Statute of Limitation to bring a lawsuit
Definition: This category covers situations regarding how long a person has to raise a claim or file a lawsuit, depending on what the statute of limitations is for this type of claim.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2023100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2023199]

Title: Computation of time for statutes of limitation
Definition: This category covers how statutes of limitation's time period are calculated.

Title: Waiving a statute of limitations
Definition: This category covers situations when a party might want to waive the time limits of a statute of limitations, and how they might get this waiver.

Title: Summary Judgment for one party before a trial's end
Definition: This category covers the option for one party in a lawsuit to request a summary judgment from the court, in which a court enters a judgment for one party without a full trial.

Title: Transcripts and Recordings of legal proceedings
Definition: This category covers if and how court proceedings are transcribed or recorded, and then how these recordings or transcripts can be requested from the court.

Title: Transferring a case to another venue
Definition: This category covers situations when a party or court may want to move the place where a court case is held, by requesting a transfer to another venue.

Title: Waiver of service of court papers
Definition: This category covers situations when a party in a lawsuit waives service of process obligations, by signing a 'waiver of service' form according to the local civil procedure rules.

Title: Lawyer's fees and payments
Definition: This category covers issues with how much a lawyer costs, what kinds of fees they may charge, and how to deal with these costs.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2010200], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2010299]

Title: Hourly Rates of a lawyer
Definition: This category covers quetsions about what kinds of hourly rates a lawyer might charge, and what to do if there is an issue with the rates or payments.

Title: Costs that lawyers are allowed to charge
Definition: This category covers what kinds of fees that lawyers can charge, including when the court has awarded attorney fees to the successful party.

Title: Having other party pay attorney fees
Definition: This category covers situations when one party in a court case may have the other side pay their attorney's fees and costs. This might be called a prevailing party clause, in which the people have agreed that whoever wins a court case would get paid back for attorney fees in the case.

Title: Attorney fees award after consent decree or settlement
Definition: This category covers how one party may request that the other party pay for their attorney fees and costs, after a case has ended in a settlelment or a consent decree (rather than a final judgment by the court).

Title: Computing attorney's fees to be paid from one party to another
Definition: This category covers how to decide how much one party owes the other for attorney's fees if they have been awarded after a case. This could be through the 'lodestar' method of calculation.

Title: Having the government pay attorney fees
Definition: This category covers situations when a person may have been in a lawsuit or other adjudication with a US government agency, and is trying to have the agency pay the attorney fees after winning the case. This includes situations in which the government may say that its position was substantially justified, and so should not have to pay attorney fees. This may be under the Equal Access to Justice Act.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2010205], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2010400]

Title: Privileged material and evidence rules
Definition: This category covers rules about what information can be used as evidence in a court case or a hearing, if that information may be subject to a privilege rule (like attorney-client confidentiality or a spousal relationship).

Title: Attorney-Client Privilege
Definition: This category covers the attorney-client privlege, what's included in this privilege, and how it applies when it comes to evidence or other requests.

Title: Websites and technology for legal help
Definition: This category covers websites, apps, and other online tools that can help a person deal with a legal problem or to find services that can help them

Title: Bar Association legal help websites
Definition: This category covers online websites, apps, and tools that bar associations may have to provide help to people with legal problems.

Title: Community resources for legal problems
Definition: This category covers legal help resources that exist within community services organizations, libraries, schools, religious organizations, food banks, neighborhood groups, and other community places.

Title: Establishing a lawyer-client relationship
Definition: This category covers issues of how a person can begin an official relationship with a lawyer, to establish an attorney-client relationship that has certain privileges and obligations.

Title: Conflicts of Interest check for a lawyer and client
Definition: This category covers issues when a person and attorney are potentially beginning an attorney-client relationship, and the attorney checks for possible conflicts of interest before they can become the person's attorney.

Title: Ethical rules for lawyer's behavior
Definition: This category covers issues around how lawyers behave toward their client and otherwise, if there are concerns about unethical or biased behavior. This covers what rules guide attorney ethics, and what they might be punished or disbarred for. It also covers how a person or client can raise an ethics complaint about a lawyer.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2011400], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2011499], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2011402]

Title: Bias of a lawyer
Definition: This category covers possible problem behavior by a lawyer, if they are acting in a biased way. It covers what rules govern what is ethical or not, and what violations or penalities they may face.

Title: Getting Legal Aid or Pro Bono lawyer help
Definition: This category covers how a person might get free help from a lawyer for a civil (not criminal) problem, through services like legal aid or pro bono programs.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2013000], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2010900], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2010999]

Title: Finding Legal Aid outside of the US
Definition: This category covers situations when a person might be outside of the US and is trying to find free or low-cost legal help there.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2011500], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2010920]

Title: Restrictions on what legal aid can do
Definition: This category covers rules and policies on what legal aid groups can provide for clients or potential clients, including limits on who they are able to serve based on income, residency, citizenship, or other factors.

Title: Paralegals and non-lawyer professionals
Definition: This category covers options and issues of working with a legal professional who is not a licensed attorney, like a paralegal or limited license technician.

Title: Retainer letters and agreements to hire a lawyer
Definition: This category covers how to establish a lawyer-client relationship through a retainer agreement, in the form of an engagement letter and possible fee payed by the client. It can be a contract that establishes the professional relationship. This category covers how to establish this agreement, and how to deal with issues or problems with it.

Title: Court-based legal help centers
Definition: This cateogry covers options that a person might have to get free legal help and information at a court, at an information or advice desk, court self-help center, or other resource.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2011060], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2011070]

Title: Filling out forms and other legal documents
Definition: This category covers resources and tools for people who filling out court forms and other legal documents.

Title: Judges' behavior with self-represented litigants
Definition: This category covers how judges may interact with a person without a lawyer, and the rules about what they can do in terms of instructions, guidance, penalties, and other issues.

Title: Court programs for self-represented litigants
Definition: This category covers programs and options that courts may provide to people wihtout lawyers in civil cases, who may be known as self-represented litigants or pro se.

Title: Education on how to represent oneself
Definition: This category covers education and training resources that a person can use when representing themselves in a legal matter.

Title: Suing the government for civil rights violations
Definition: This category covers a person's options to sue the government for possible civil rights violations they have suffered by a government agency or official. This might be called a Section 1983 lawsuit. It might involve lawsuits against the police for the use of excessive force.

Title: Getting civil rights lawyer's fees paid
Definition: This category covers the possibility that a person could get their civil rights attorney's fees paid for, after they have brought a lawsuit around civil rights violations they have experienced. This could be called Section 1988.

Title: Age Discrimination
Definition: This category covers situations where a person may have experienced discrimination based on their age. This could be at work, in a consumer context, or by other private or government actors.

Title: Rights when dealing with the government
Definition: This category covers what rights a person has when dealing with government agents like police, prosecutors, courts, administrative agencies, prison officials, and others. This includes rights and protections for when someone is under investigation, having to go to court, applying for government benefits, protesting, or other activities that might put them in contact with the government.

Title: Rights against government depriving one of liberty
Definition: This category concerns situations where a person feels that the government may be depriving them of their liberty (by arresting, jailing, or otherwise impeding their free choices and movement) without giving them 'due process' to defend themselves and to use the law. Deprivation of liberty could be stopping peopel from using their freedom to travel, freedom to live with and raise children, freedom from incarceration, or freedom to not be subjected to violence or medical treatments.

Title: Rights against government depriving one of property
Definition: This category covers due process rights that a person might have, when the government may be threatening to take their property. This could include objects, money, real estate, or jobs that a person has entitlement to. The due process right given by the Constitution's 14th Amendment says that the government should give sufficient process (like hearings, counsel, cross-examining witnesses, neutral decision-making, or other process) before taking this property away from a person.

Title: Remedies if government violates one's due process
Definition: This category covers what options a person has if the government has deprived them of their Consitutional rights, by taking away their liberty, property, or life without giving them sufficient procedural protections to defend themselves.

Title: First Amendment protections of freedom of religion
Definition: This category covers situations where a person feels their freedom of religion is being limited by a government agent, or that the government is attempting to establish a national religion. The Constitution's First Amendment prohibits laws that attempt to establish a national religion, or that impede the free exercise of a religion.

Title: First Amendment protections of freedom of association
Definition: This category covers what rights a person has under the First Amendment to associate with others, including to organize around political and social ideas that might challenge the government.

Title: First Amendment protections of freedom of speech
Definition: This category covers what rights a person has under the First Amendment freedom of speech clause, including to express themselves and protest without the government interfering in this expression.

Title: HIV/AIDS discrimination
Definition: This category covers what rights people with HIV/AIDS have, to be protected from discrimination or in getting assistance. It also covers privacy protections for people's health information. This could be in situations at work, health care facilities, schools, daycares, pools, gyms, and other places.

Title: Language Access rights
Definition: This category covers people's rights to get assistance with English in order to access government services and public programs, including rights to have an interpreter, to have important documents translated into another language, and to register complaints if they don't get equal treatment based on their language.

Title: HIV/AIDS care and rights
Definition: This category covers what people dealing with AIDS/HIV have in terms of protections and rights, and resources when dealing with health issues.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1590200], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1590203]

Title: Health care for those with HIV/AIDS
Definition: This category covers what resources and rights a person with HIV/AIDS has.

Title: Abortion care and rights
Definition: This category covers what rights or limits a person has to access abortion care, and what resources there might be to receive medical care.

Title: Alcoholism and Substance Abuse
Definition: This category covers options for treatment, services, and protections for those dealing with alcoholism, drug dependency, or other substance abuse.

Title: Birth Control and Sterlization
Definition: This category covers options, rights, and protection a person has in regards to birth control or sterilization procedures.

Title: Black Lung Disease (Pneumoconiosis) benefits
Definition: This category covers medical and financial benefits and protections for a person (like, a coal miner) who suffers from black lung disease, or pneumoconiosis. It could also cover the benefits to the survivors of the person who died from the disease. These benefits are provided for under the Black Lung Benefits Act.

Title: Breast and Cervical Cancer
Definition: This category covers screening, treatment, and options for women facing possible breast or cervical cancer.

Title: Children's Health Insurance Programs (CHIP) for kids and pregnant women
Definition: This category covers options for children to get their health care costs paid for through a state CHIP, the public benefits program Children's Health Insurance Program. It is provided for children in families that earn too much money to qualify for Medicaid, and sometimes for pregnant women.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1530000], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1530099], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [53]

Title: Eligibility for Children's Health Insurance Programs
Definition: This category covers the rules and process for applying for health insurance coverage through a state CHIP program. It covers the limits on who qualifies for a CHIP, and how to apply to get covered through a CHIP.

Title: Appealing denial of CHIP coverage
Definition: This category covers how a person can appeal a denial of CHIP eligibility or coverage for a certain procedure.

Title: Dental services through CHIP
Definition: This category covers what options and coverage a person on CHIP program has for dental services for problems with their teeth or gums.

Title: Coverage of health issues on CHIP
Definition: This category covers what medical conditions and procedures that CHIP programs cover for kids and pregnant women.

Title: Early Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment program for children
Definition: This category covers options for children and pregnant women to get medical care through the EPSDT (Early Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment) program.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1530400], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1510800]

Title: Children's protections against Lead Poisoning and Asthma
Definition: This category covers options through CHIP and related Healthy Homes programs to get health care and other services to children dealing with lead poisoning, asthma, and other home hazards because of living conditions.

Title: COBRA coverage for dependents
Definition: This category covers options for dependents of an employee to get COBRA health insurance coverage, including when the employee dies; the adult child dependent turns 26 or can't stay on the plan; there is a divorce or legal separation; or the employee becomes eligible for Medicare.

Title: Counseling and social work needs
Definition: This category covers what options and rights a person might have to get services from a counselor or a social worker.

Title: Language and cultural access to health care
Definition: This category covers what rights and options a person has to receive health care in a language that they can understand, and that is culturally appropriate to them.

Title: Discrimination or Refusal to Treat a person
Definition: This category covers discrimination a person might face when seeking medical care, including possibly when the provider refuses to treat them. This covers when doctors are obliged to provide services, or what a person can do if the health care provider says they have an objection to provide services to a certain patient (like women and LGBTQ individuals).

Title: Duty to provide health care to low-income individuals
Definition: This category covers what duties a health care provider has to people who cannot afford to pay for medical care.

Title: Free and Low-Cost medical care
Definition: This category covers options and services that provide people with free care, or low-cost care.

Title: Medicaid Home And Community Based Services
Definition: This category covers options for Medicaid beneficiaries to receive services in their own home or community through the HCBS (Home And Community Based Services) program. It might be for people with intellectual or developmental disabilities, physical disabilities, or mental illnesses. It is provided under a waiver, to allow the program to operate differently from the typical rules.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1540000], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1512500], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [54]

Title: Immigrants' access to health care
Definition: This category covers issues that immigrants to the US might have when trying to access health care, including programs that cover the costs of care like Medicaid, Medicare, or CHIP.

Title: Eligibility and applications for Medicaid
Definition: This category covers the rules about who can be covered for Medicaid benefits, and how to apply for them.

Title: Immigrants' eligibility for Medicaid
Definition: This category covers whether an immigrant on a certain visa or status may be eligible for Medicaid benefits to cover health and medical costs.

Title: Immunization and Vaccines
Definition: This category covers options, rights, and obligations around getting immunizations and vaccines.

Title: Managed Care plans
Definition: This category covers options for a person on a managed care plan, in which a health insurance plan coordinates with providers. This might be through a private provider or a Medicaid program.

Title: Free or low-cost care through Hill-Burton facilities
Definition: This category covers the rules and options to get free or low-cost care through hospitals, nursing homes, or other facilities that are part of the Hill-Burton program. These facilities must notify the public that free or affordable services are available, and then provide services to people who qualify.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1591000], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1591099], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1591001], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1591002]

Title: Minority groups' access to health care
Definition: This category covers options and rights that members of minority groups have to get quality health care, and to deal with possible discrimination or low-quality care.

Title: Prescription Drug payment assistance
Definition: This category covers programs and options that people might have to get their prescription drugs paid for.

Title: Quality of care in a nursing home
Definition: This category covers rights and options for a person who is unhappy with the quality of care in a nursing home.

Title: Medicaid coverage of particular procedures or treatments
Definition: This category covers issues about whether Medicaid assistance programs will cover the expenses of particular medical procedures, devices, treatments, services, or equipment.

Title: Medicaid coverage of abortion
Definition: This category covers whether Medicaid will cover the costs of abortion procedures.

Title: Appealing Medicaid decisions
Definition: This category covers how a person can appeal a decision made by a Medicaid program. This could be around eligibility for Medicaid coverage, or whether a particular treatment or device is covered by the program.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1511700], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1511799]

Title: Appealing Medicaid coverage decision
Definition: This category covers how a person can appeal a Medicaid program's decision about whether a particular medical cost is covered.

Title: Appealing Medicaid decision on eligibility
Definition: This category covers how a person could appeal a Medicaid program's decision on whether they are eligible for coverage in the program.

Title: Application process for Medicaid
Definition: This category covers issues of applying to be covered by a Medicaid program, including the rules on eligibility, and the steps involved in applying.

Title: Asset Limits for Medicaid eligibility
Definition: This category covers how a person's assets (like their money, property, and other things they own) determine if they are eligible for Medicaid coverage or not. This includes how assets are calculated, and what limits determine if they qualify or not.

Title: Available Income and eligibility for Medicaid
Definition: This category covers how a person's income affects if they are eligible for Medicaid coverage, and how this available income is calculated.

Title: Medicaid coverage of breast and cervical cancer treatment
Definition: This category is about Medicaid programs' coverage of women's treatments for breast and cervical cancer screening and care.

Title: Medicaid coverage of birth control and family planning
Definition: This category covers whether and how Medicaid programs cover the costs of birth control and family planning treatments.

Title: Medicaid coverage of dental services
Definition: This category covers whether and how Medicaid programs cover the costs of dental services to deal with teeth and gum issues.

Title: Cost-sharing, Premiums, and Out-of-Pocket costs on Medicaid
Definition: This category covers what costs a person might expect to pay while covered by Medicaid, including premiums, cost-shares, and other out-of-pocket payments they would need to make. This also covers issues when a person may be protected from cost-sharing, because they belong to a vulnerable group (like children or pregnant women) or because of state rules.

Title: Medicaid coverage of Durable Medical Equipment
Definition: This category covers whether and how Medicaid programs cover the cost of medically necessary durable medical equipment (DME) for a person to use at home, like wheelchairs, canes, scooters, walkers, crutches, hospital beds, diabetes testing materials, infusion pumps lifts, and other supplies.

Title: Medicaid coverage of optical services
Definition: This category covers whether and how Medicaid covers eye treatments, with opticians or other optical services.

Title: Being eligible for both Medicaid and Medicare
Definition: This category covers the situations when a person is eligible for both Medicaid and Medicare programs (as a Dual-Eligible beneficiary), and how they might combine the assistance to have them work together to cover costs.

Title: Medicaid Overpayment and Recoupment
Definition: This category covers situations when a Medicaid program may have overpaid, and when they will try to recoup payments through demand letters or collections actions. This covers how to challenge an overpayment demand, report an overpayment, how the collection process will work, whether interest will be charged, and what the lookback period will be.

Title: Medicaid coverage of prescriptions
Definition: This category covers whether and how Medicaid programs cover the costs of prescription drugs.

Title: Suing to enforce the Medicaid Act
Definition: This category covers how a private individual or group may try to enforce the Medicaid Act by suing the state government, requesting that they enforce the requirements of the Act. This may be a Medicaid beneficiary or provider that wants the government to behave as the Act requires.

Title: Spend Down strategy to be eligible for Medicaid
Definition: This category covers a situation in which a person may use a Spend Down financial strategy when their income or assets are too high to qualify for Medicaid. This strategy involves spending some of the person's income or assets on health and medical costs, or debt, in order to become eligible for Medicaid.

Title: Termination of Medicaid
Definition: This category covers when a person's Medicaid benefits are terminated or canceled. This could be because of changes in income or household size, failure to fill in a redetermination form, or other reason. This covers how to appeal this termination.

Title: Transferring assets to qualify for Medicaid
Definition: This category covers whether and how a person might transfer assets in order to qualify for Medicaid, and what penalties they might face if the agency determines they did this incorrectly.

Title: Underpayment by Medicaid
Definition: This program covers situations when the Medicaid program underpays reimbursements to providers or others for the costs of care.

Title: Assisted Living or Board and Care homes
Definition: This category covers options for board and care homes or assisted living arrangements, to help support individuals who need support with medical care and daily activities.

Title: Discharge or transfer from a nursing home
Definition: This category covers whether and how a person can be transferred out of a nursing home or discharged from it. This includes issues around the consent of the person, and obligations of the nursing home around discharge or transfer.

Title: Licensing of nursing homes
Definition: This category covers how to become licensed and look up whether a nursing home is licensed.

Title: Commitment to a mental health facility
Definition: This category covers how a person may be committed to a mental health facility, either voluntarily or involuntarily. It covers what rights a person has, what other people's ability to commit them are, and what options or procedures must be followed.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1820100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1820199]

Title: Voluntary commitment to a mental health facility
Definition: This category covers situations when a person is committed to a mental health facility with their voluntary consent. It covers the procedures of commitment, and a person's rights.

Title: Involuntary Commitment to a mental health facility
Definition: This category covers the procedures that must be followed to commit a person to a mental health facility against their will, as an involuntary commitment. This could also be called an emergency hold, 72-hour hold, a pick-up, an involuntary hold, an emergency commitment, a psychiatric hold, a temporary detention order, or an emergency petition.

Title: Rights when being committed to a mental health facility
Definition: This category covers what rights a person has if they are being committed to a mental health facility, either voluntarily or involuntarily.

Title: Rights to refuse mental health treatment
Definition: This category covers what rights a person has to refuse a possible treatment for mental health issues.

Title: Right to mental health treatment
Definition: This category covers what rights a person has to get treatment, and other health and medical care for their mental health issues.

Title: Community programs for mental health
Definition: This category covers options and rights to community programs that can assist with mental health needs.

Title: Least Restrictive Alternative Standard for mental health care
Definition: This category covers what standards there are for mental health care, particularly a legal standard to use the least restrictive alternative in treating the person. This could also be part of a court's assessment that a person should go to an Assisted Outpatient Treatment facility is the least restrictive alternative for the person -- so that they should be ordered treatment at this facility.

Title: Mental Health facilities and institutions
Definition: This category covers issues that a person might have with a mental health facility or institution. It could be about quality of care, infringement of rights, procedures to access care, or to raise complaints.

Title: Eligibility and Applications for Medicare
Definition: This category covers the eligibility rules about who can be covered by Medicare benefits, and how a person can apply for them.

Title: Application process for Medicare
Definition: This category covers how a person can apply for Medicare, what steps to follow, and how to deal with issues that arise in the application process.

Title: Appealing Medicare decisions
Definition: This category covers how one can challenge a decision that a Medicare program has made about their eligibility, coverage, termination, or other issue with the program.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1521400], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1521499]

Title: Medicare coverage of particular procedures or treatments
Definition: This category covers issues about whether Medicare assistance programs will cover the expenses of particular medical procedures, devices, treatments, services, or equipment.

Title: Appealing Medicare coverage decisions
Definition: This category covers how a person can appeal a Medicare program's decision about whether a particular medical cost for a treatment, procedure, or condition is covered.

Title: Appealing Medicare eligibility decision
Definition: This category covers how a person could appeal a Medicare program's decision on whether they are eligible for coverage in the program.

Title: Cost-sharing, Premiums, and Out-of-Pocket costs on Medicare
Definition: This category covers what costs a person might expect to pay while covered by Medicare, including premiums, cost-shares, and other out-of-pocket payments they would need to make. This also covers issues when a person may be protected from cost-sharing, because they belong to a vulnerable group.

Title: Termination of Medicare coverage
Definition: This category covers when a person's Medicare benefits are terminated or canceled. This could be because of changes in income or household size, compliance issues, or other reason. This covers how to appeal this termination.

Title: Medicare coverage of extended care, rehab, and nursing care
Definition: This category covers whether and how Medicare programs cover extended care services, such as skilled nursing care, rehabilitation services, and other services for when people leave the hospital.

Title: Medicare coverage of hospital services
Definition: This category covers whether and how Medicare programs cover hospital services for beneficiaries.

Title: Income limits on Medicare eligibility
Definition: This category covers what income limits there might be for Medicare eligibility, and what happens if one's income exceeds the limit while they are on Medicare.

Title: Medicare coverage of skilled nursing care
Definition: This category covers whether and how Medicare will cover treatment of skilled nursing care.

Title: Underpayment by Medicare program
Definition: This category covers what happens if Medicare programs underpay health care costs.

Title: Overpayment and recoupment of Medicare payments
Definition: This category covers what happens if Medicare overpays costs, and how it might try to recoup or collect this money.

Title: Medigap Supplement Insurance for Medicare beneficiaries
Definition: This category covers options and rights for a person considering a supplemental insurance program (Medigap) while on Medicare, from a private company to help cover health care services and supply costs that Medicare does not pay.

Title: Medicare Part A for inpatient care
Definition: This category covers issues with Medicare Part A, that covers inpatient care hospital or nursing facility costs for its beneficiaries.

Title: Medicare Part B for outpatient services and equipment
Definition: This category covers issues with Medicare Part B, that covers doctor and health care providers' services and outpatient care, as well as medical supplies, equipment, home health care, and preventative services.

Title: Medicare Part C (Medicare Advantage)
Definition: This category covers issues with Medicare Part C, that has private insurance companies providing coverage of inpatient and outpatient services, treatments, visits, equipment, and other benefits. This can be an alternative to Medicare A and B.

Title: Medicare Part D for prescription drugs
Definition: This category covers issues with Medicare Part D, that covers prescription drug costs.

Title: Complaining about medical services quality or cost
Definition: This category covers a person's options to complain about the quality or cost of medical services to an ombudsman, ombudsprogram, or consumer assistance group at a facility.

Title: Disability rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)
Definition: This category concerns what rights the ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act) gives to people, who is covered by it, and what obligations it imposes on businesses and people.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1840100], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1840199], Wikidata Taxonomy [Q56659801]

Title: Websites' accessibility requirements
Definition: This category covers what requirements there are for websites to be accessible to people with disabilities, including under the Americans with Disability Act (ADA). It also covers how people can raise complaints about lack of accessibility. It covers which websites must comply with accessibility standards, and what 'reasonable accessibility' means.

Title: Reasonable Accommodation standard under ADA
Definition: This category covers issues with interpreting whether a group is compliant with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) or not, and whether they have offered reasonable accommodation to people with disabilities to use their buildings, websites, services, and other offerings.

Title: Accessibility rights under ADA
Definition: This category covers what rights the Americans with Disabilities Act gives to people with disabilities, to have facilities, goods, services, and technologies be made accessible to them.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1840101], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1840103]

Title: ADA Section 508 accessibility for federal government
Definition: This category covers situations when the American with Disabilities Act (ADA) requires that federal government agencies and services -- especially their technology and information tools -- be made accessible to people with disabilities. This includes which agencies this applies to, what it requires of them in development, procurement, and maintenance, and how people can complain about it.

Title: Architectural barriers and accessibility under the ADA
Definition: This category covers what requirements physical spaces and buildings must comply with, in order to comply with the accessibility rules of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). This includes which buildings must be in compliance, what constitutes an architectural barrier, and how people can make complaints.

Title: Disability issues and rights
Definition: This category covers issues that people with a physical or mental disability may be dealing with, including around education, rights, work, estate planning, or other issues.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1840000], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1840099], Wikidata Taxonomy [Q15978181]

Title: Health public benefits for a person with a disability
Definition: This category covers what options a person with a disability has to get public benefits to cover the cost of their medical care. This could include coverage through Medicaid, Medicare, or state programs.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1840500], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1840599]

Title: Medicaid coverage for a person with a disability
Definition: This category covers what Medicaid benefits a person with a disability might be eligible for, and how they can access this coverage. This includes how to apply to get it, how it works with other insurance, what protections against discrimination works, and what special management plans might be.

Title: Medicare coverage for a person with a disability
Definition: This category covers what Medicare benefits a person with a disability might be eligible for, and how they can access this coverage. This includes how to apply to get it, how it works with other insurance, what protections against discrimination works, and what special management plans might be.

Title: Mental Health Disabilities
Definition: This category covers situations when mental health issues are considered as disabilities, and what kinds of options, rights, and services people in this situation have to claim benefits and protect their well-being.

Title: Assistive technology for students with disabilities
Definition: This category covers what rights a student with disabilities may have to get technology that helps them learn at schools, and what laws (like the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA)) requires of schools.

Title: Disability and eligibility for SNAP food stamps
Definition: This category covers whether and how people with a disability are eligible for SNAP food stamps, to be used through electronic benefits transfer cards.

Title: In-home supportive service disability benefits
Definition: This category covers options for public benefits, often provided by state programs, to cover in-home supportive services for a person with a disability. This could be to cover someone to help with chores, home-making, and other home needs.

Title: Disability discrimination in government programs
Definition: This category covers what protections a person with a disability might against discrimination in programs from federal government agencies, groups receiving government assistance, or contractors. This might be under the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and its prohibition on disability-based discrimination in the federal government.

Title: Disability services and resources
Definition: This category covers resources, services, and other options for assistance to people who are dealing with physical or mental disabilities.

Title: Applications and Eligibility for TANF
Definition: This category covers how to apply for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits, who is eligible for them, how these determinations are made, and how one can contest the decisions around the application.

Title: Application process for TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers how to apply for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits, what to expect from the process, and how to raise complaints with it.

Title: Eligibility standards for TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers who is eligible for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits, what the standards are, how they are applied, and how to raise concerns with them.

Title: Income, assets, and eligibility for TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers how a person's income may affect whether they are eligible to receive Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits, and how the income is calculated, including available income and income disregards.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1711800], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1711899]

Title: Available income for TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers how one can show and calculate their available income, when applying to receive Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits.

Title: Income disregards for TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers what does not count as one's available income, when applying for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits. These may be called income disregards.

Title: Assets and resources' effect on TANF benefits eligibility
Definition: This category covers how a family's assets and resources may affect whether they are eligible to receive Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits, and how the assets and resources are calculated, including homes, property, other benefits, savings accounts, and other things.

Title: Amount of money received through TANF
Definition: This category concerns how much money a family receives through the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program and how this is calculated. This includes situations when the benefit amount is calculated only based on children, and not on adults in the family.

Title: Child-Only TANF benefit calculations
Definition: This category covers situations when the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program provides financial benefits based only on the children in the family, rather than adults. This could be when children live with relatives or nonrelatives instead of their parents, or if their parents are ineligible for TANF for non-income reasons.

Title: Child exclusions and family caps for TANF benefit calculations
Definition: This category covers situations in which a family receives support through the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program, but does not get extra money for certain children in the family. This could be because of a state's family cap or child exclusion policy, for instance when a family on TANF has another child and that child is considered ineligible for TANF (and the family's benefit amount remains the same).

Title: TANF and child support obligations
Definition: This category covers situations in which parents receive benefits through the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program, and the effect it has on their child support rights and obligations. This could include working with the state to identify the other parent, establish paternity, settle child support orders, complete child support modifications, enforce child support, and assign child support collections to the state.

Title: Medicaid and child support obligations
Definition: This category covers situations in which parents receive benefits through the Medicaid program, and the effect it has on their child support rights and obligations. This could include working with the state to identify the other parent, establish paternity, settle child support orders, complete child support modifications, enforce child support, and assign child support collections to the state.

Title: TANF diversion programs
Definition: This category covers state programs that mean to divert people away from enrolling for the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program, and instead go through diversion programs that encourage work, or give lump-sum payments or vouchers.  These often are temporary support programs that encourage rapid employment. It could be under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (PRWORA).

Title: Appealing a TANF benefits decision
Definition: This category covers whether and how a person can appeal a decision made by a Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program. This could be appealing an eligibility determination, termination of benefits, the calculation of benefits, denial of benefits, or other decisions.

Title: Due process protections around TANF
Definition: This category covers what rights a person has to receive notices and hearings around Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program benefits. This could be if they have been denied benefits, terminated from the program, or another decision by the program. This category covers whether they are entitled to notices and hearings about these decisions, and how they might be able to challenge them before their benefit is taken away.

Title: Receiving TANF benefits through electronic benefits transfer (EBT)
Definition: This category covers issues with receiving the correct amount of money from the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program, and accessing the funds through electronic benefits transfer (EBT) card or account.

Title: Emergency TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers how a family might be able to get emergency funds through the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program. These typically are short-term, temporary programs, that may be extended if the family applies for the regular TANF benefits.

Title: Defining the family unit for TANF eligibility
Definition: This category covers how the family size is determined when assessing TANF eligibility, including who is considered an essential person and what the family budget unit is.

Title: Fraud in receiving TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers situations in which a person receiving the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program benefits is accused of fraud. It covers what is considered fraud, what procedures to investigate and prosecute it might be, how a person can defend themselves from charges of fraud, and what penalties might result. It can also involve reporting fraud. It may be called "welfare fraud".

Title: Immigrants' Eligibility for TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers whether and if non-citizens in the US are able to receive benefits through the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program.

Title: Requirements to stay on TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers what a person must do to stay on TANF benefits after they have been accepted to receive them. This includes mandatory job search and work requirements, as well as efforts to work towards goals.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1713200], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1713299]

Title: Job search requirements for TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers a person's requirements to conduct job searches in order to stay on TANF benefits. This includes how a person can choose which kind of job search they do -- through a county assistance office or a contracted agency -- and how they must follow the rules to continue getting benefits.

Title: Lump Sum Payments to TANF applicants
Definition: This category covers the option of a TANF (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) applicant to receive lump sum payments as a diversion from the program. The lump sum gives a one-time amount of money to a family to address the situation that has led them to apply for TANF. It would be a diversion from enrolling in typical TANF benefits.

Title: Over- or Under-payment of TANF Benefits
Definition: This category covers issues that TANF benefit recipients may have, with an incorrect amount of money they've received through the program. It could be when the program notifies them of an overpayment and recoupment problem, or when they feel they are being underpaid.

Title: Overpayment and Recoupment of TANF Benefits
Definition: This category covers situations when a TANF recipient has been overpaid with benefits, or the agency has told them that there has been an overpayment and are going to recoup the overpaid money.

Title: Underpayment of TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers situations when a TANF recipient has not been paid the benefit amount that they were supposed to receive. It covers what options they have to try to resolve the situation and get the right amount of benefits.

Title: Residency requirements to receive TANF
Definition: This category covers the state or country residence requirements to be eligible for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits. Each state's agency can set the rules of who in their state can receive TANF from them, how to show this, and how to contest a denial based on residency.

Title: Money sanctions for TANF recipients
Definition: This category covers situations when a family receiving Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits receives a sanction that reduces the amount of money they receive. There may be a sanction if the adult in the family does not follow work requirements.

Title: Housing or Shelter Allowance on TANF
Definition: This category covers what additional money a recipient of Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits may get, to cover costs of housing or shelter.

Title: TANF standards to calculate financial need
Definition: This category covers the 'standard of need' determination that Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) programs use to decide on whether a family is eligible to receive benefits, and how much they should receive.

Title: TANF amounts for support services
Definition: This category covers the extra support services benefits that recipients of the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program can get to cover other costs they need.

Title: Teen parents' eligibility for TANF
Definition: This category covers situations when a teen parent is applying for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits, and how they might be eligible for TANF.

Title: Termination of TANF benefits
Definition: This category covers what happens if a family's Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits are canceled or terminated. It also covers how this could be challenged.

Title: Time limit on receiving TANF
Definition: This category covers the time limit on how long a person can receive Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits. The TANF benefits may expire after a certain amount of months set by the government.

Title: TANF Assessments and Individual Responsibility Plans
Definition: This category covers TANF recipients' requirements to create an individual responsibility plan, go through screening and assessments, and follow these plans to stay on benefits.

Title: TANF work requirements and education or vocational training
Definition: This category covers how a recipient of TANF benefits may do vocational training or education to count as work activity requirements to continue receiving benefits.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1713203], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1713205], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1713206]

Title: Native American children's custody by non-parents (Indian Child Welfare Act)
Definition: This category covers the rules and protections of how Native American children's custody may be changed, including under the Indian Child Welfare Act that sets state court rules about child custody. This could be around adoption, foster care placement, termination of parental rights, when a 3rd party (non-parent) files for custody, or other situations when a Native American child is placed outside their home.

Title: Native American hunting and fishing rights
Definition: This category covers what special rights that Native Americans have to hunt and fish on their own territory and other places.

Title: Indian Health Service
Definition: This category covers issues around the Indian Health Service agency, that provides medical help and public health services to Native Americans and Alaska Native people.

Title: Jurisdiction of Native American tribes
Definition: This category covers issues around what jurisdiction Native American tribal governments and courts might have over legal questions, cases, crimes, and other matters of government and law. This also covers who has jurisdiction on Indian reservations, and what laws apply to Native American tribe members.

Title: Native American reservations
Definition: This category covers issues around Native American reservations, who can live there, what protections they have, and what happens with the and natural resources there.

Title: Sovereignty of Native American tribes
Definition: This category covers issues around the rights of Native Americans and Alaska Natives to have tribal sovereignty, in order to govern themselves. This includes rights under the US Constitution to have their own government and powers akin to federal and state governments.

Title: Treaties and Native Americans
Definition: This category covers what treaties set laws, obligations, and rules for Native American tribes and the US government under the "Indian treaties", including guaranteed protections for education, health care, housing, and other services, as well as the management of natural resources and land.

Title: Tribal Government
Definition: This category covers what government structures exist for Native Americans and Native Alaskans, how they relate to US federal and state governments, how they establish laws, and how they administer benefits and other services.

Title: Tribal TANF
Definition: This category covers options for American Indians and Alaska Natives to receive Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) through a specific benefits program called Tribal TANF. This provides cash aids and supportive services to needy children and families who apply.

Title: Protections for students with disabilities
