Definition: This category covers rights and protections for students with disabilities. This includes protection under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Ac (ADA), Section 504 civil rights law, and the ADA.

Title: Language access to education
Definition: This category covers issues of getting public education that is bilingual or that is accessible to students with limited English proficiency.

Title: Desegregation of schools
Definition: This category covers issues with programs to desegregate school systems, or about options to promote desegregation to ensure equal access to quality education.

Title: Expulsion from school
Definition: This category covers a student and parent's options and rights when the school is trying to expel the student.

Title: Suspension from school
Definition: This category covers a student or parent's rights when the school is trying to suspend the student from school.

Title: Exclusion of students from activities
Definition: This category covers options for a student and parents if the student is being excluded from activities, like field trips, school programs, or other activities at the school.

Title: Fees for educational programs
Definition: This category covers issues for students or their families regarding covering fees at their school

Title: Head Start services for families
Definition: This category covers students' and families' options around the Head Start Program from the US Department of Health and Human Services, that provides early childhood education, health, nutrition, and parenting services to low-income families and children. This covers who is eligible, how to apply, and how to receive services.

Title: Vouchers to pay for private education
Definition: This category covers situations in which a family wants to get vouchers from the government to cover the costs of tuition at private schools. Not all states offer school vouchers. This covers how to get traditional vouchers, education saving accounts (ESAs) or tax credit scholarships.  It covers eligibility for vouchers, enrollment with a voucher, discipline, and special education needs.

Title: Quality of education for student with disability
Definition: This category covers issues with the quality of education that a student is receiving, and how that standard is defined or how the quality of the education a school is providing can be challenged.

Title: Individual Education Plans
Definition: This category covers issues around Individual Education Plans, or IEP's, to get quality education for a child's needs, particularly to deal with special needs or disability issues. This can cover how a parent can advocate for a student, make an IEP, make sure it is being followed, and have it changed as needed.

Title: Students' Educational Records
Definition: This category covers how a student or parents can access their educational records, including in order to advocate for an individual education plan or challenge the quality of education being received.

Title: Truancy and attendance
Definition: This category covers issues when a student has issues with attending school, skipping school, or being truant. This includes what consequences the student and their family, parents, and guardians may face if there is a problem with truancy. This includes how a school may notify the parents of truancy, visits to the home by an officer, meetings at school, and the possibility of going to the juvenile justice system.

Title: School funding for quality education
Definition: This category covers what funding schools can get, like under Title I, especially for low-income students to improve their educational outcomes.

Title: Discrimination based on sex/gender at a school (Title IX)
Definition: This category covers situations when a student feels they may be facing discrimination based on their sex in an educational program or activity that receives federal financial assistance, under the Title IX law. This could be that they're excluded from participation in a program, denied benefits, or subjected to discrimination.

Title: Vocational education
Definition: This category covers issues around vocational education, including requirements around receiving benefits or government support dependent on vocational educational and job training.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1150000], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [15], Legal Server Index Taxonomy [LS002-00015]

Title: Being a witness to a crime
Definition: This category covers rights, protections, and obligations of a person who has witnessed a crime.

Title: Victim's Rights
Definition: This category covers what rights a crime victim has, or that their survivors or family have.

Title: Witness Identification of suspects
Definition: This category covers how witnesses may be asked to identify a suspect through police lineups, photographs, or show-ups. It also covers how this ID procedure may be challenged as unreliable.

Title: Appealing criminal court's decision
Definition: This category covers how a criminal defendant may appeal the court's decision, and what the court procedure is for appeals.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2040300], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2040399]

Title: Courts of appeal
Definition: This category covers the court procedure of appealing a criminal court's decision, including which court of appeals or intermediate appellate court a defendant can take their appeal to.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2040320], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2040330]

Title: Preservation of error in a criminal case to have appeal
Definition: This category covers the options of a defendant in a criminal court to preserve an error, by raising them during litigation and trial so they could later raise them for review in an appeal to an appellate court. It also covers what happens if this process has not been done correctly, and if the appellate court says the opportunity to appeal has been waived.

Title: Clemency process for granting a pardon or reduction
Definition: This category covers the process called 'clemency' in which a government official or body reduces a person's criminal sentence or grants them a pardon. This could include clemency for death penalty cases. It also includes how a person can petition the governor, president, or other government body to grant them clemency.

Title: Criminal trial process
Definition: This category covers how criminal trials proceed, some of the issues and technical/procedural key stages, and how a defendant can protect their rights or victims and their families may be able to participate.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2041600], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2041699]

Title: Criminal trial jury selection
Definition: This category covers how a jury can be selected in a criminal trial, and what challenges or issues may arise.

Title: Jury instructions in a criminal trial
Definition: This category covers what instructions are given to jurors in a criminal jury trial, that lets them know what they should be paying attention to and how they should make their decision.

Title: Lawyers' arguments and behavior during criminal trial
Definition: This category covers issues about how lawyers behave during a criminal trial, including for the prosecution and defense. This covers issues about their conduct or problems with it, and what they can include in their arguments.

Title: Crimes against property
Definition: This category covers crimes that are against property (and not against a person). This could include burglary, vandalism, arson or theft in which a person's property is stolen or destroyed.

Title: Crimes against a person
Definition: This category covers the types of crime in which people are directly harmed, including murder, rape, or assault. This is as opposed to crimes against property in which the crime harms a person's relationship with their property.

Title: Crime Victim Compensation
Definition: This category covers what financial compensation a crime victim may be entitled to, and how to claim it.

Title: Collateral appeal to court after conviction
Definition: This category covers options for a defendant to make a 'collateral appeal' (rather than a direct appeal) after being convicted, to challenge their imprisonment or the guilty verdict. This could be through a petition for habeas corpus, a position for a new trial, a motion to void correct sentence, or claim ineffective assistance of counsel.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2041800], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2041899]

Title: Appealing based on ineffective assistance of counsel
Definition: This category covers how a criminal defendant can appeal their verdict by claiming that their defense lawyer did not correctly and fully represent them at trial, by claiming ineffective assistance of counsel in an appeal. This could be through a collateral review process.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2041810], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2040900]

Title: Coercion of a confession
Definition: This category covers situations when a person makes a statement to the police or others, and feels that they have been coerced to make a statement that incriminates them. This covers how they may challenge the reliability of the statement or confession based on coercion.

Title: False confessions
Definition: This category covers situations in which a suspect or criminal defendant might have made a false confession, or wants to challenge the statement they have given to be false.

Title: Challenging a confession based on mental capacity
Definition: This category covers issues with a suspect or defendant's confession to a crime, based on their mental capacity. It includes how the confession could be challenged based on mental capacity. This also includes protections for people with mental disabilities who make statements to the police.

Title: Right to challenge witnesses
Definition: This category covers criminal defendants' rights under the US Constitution's Confrontation Clause to challenge the prosecution's witnesses and to dispute their testimony.

Title: Quality of criminal lawyer's work and ineffective assistance of counsel
Definition: This category covers issues with how well a defendant is represented by their lawyer, and whether they can claim ineffective assistance of counsel to challenge their trial's outcome in court.

Title: Defenses against criminal charges
Definition: This category covers what defenses a person can raise when they are charged with a crime and on trial.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2040200], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2040600], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2040699]

Title: Criminal defense around lack of capacity or insanity
Definition: This category covers a possible criminal defense of saying the defendant lacked capacity or sanity, and so cannot be guilty.

Title: Self-defense as a criminal defense
Definition: This category covers how a criminal defendant may defend themselves at trial by claiming self-defense as the reason they violated the law.

Title: Evidence at a criminal trial
Definition: This category covers what kind of evidence can be brought into a criminal trial, how it can be challenged, and what it can be used for.

Title: Forensic evidence about a crime
Definition: This category covers what kinds of forensic evidence can be brought into a criminal trial, including ballistics, blood tests, DNA tests, and other tests from scientific methods that can show guilt or innocence.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2042610], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2042619]

Title: Ballistics evidence
Definition: This category covers how ballistic evidence can be brought into a criminal trial to analyze how weapons have been used and what that means for a person's guilt or innocence.

Title: Hair and fiber evidence
Definition: This category covers how evidence about hair and fiber may be brought into a criminal trial to prove a person's guilt or innocence.

Title: Fingerprint and impression evidence
Definition: This category covers what kinds of fingerprint or other impression evidence can be brought into a criminal trial to prove a defendant's guilt or innocence.

Title: Expert testimony at a criminal trial
Definition: This category covers how experts may be brought into a criminal trial to discuss evidence or opinions about the defendant's guilt or innocence.

Title: Blood and body fluid evidence
Definition: This category covers serology evidence, about blood or other body fluids, used at a criminal trial to show guilt or innocence of a criminal defendant.

Title: Genetic evidence at a criminal trial
Definition: This category covers what kind of genetic evidence can be brought into a criminal trial to show a defendant's guilt or innocence. This includes DNA evidence.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2042620], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2042629], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2042622]

Title: DNA evidence at a criminal trial
Definition: This category covers how DNA evidence might be brought into a criminal trial to prove a defendant's guilt or innocence.

Title: Challenging genetic evidence as junk science
Definition: This category covers how evidence at a criminal trial can be challenged as junk science.

Title: Grand Juries and being indicted for a crime
Definition: This category covers how a grand jury works to formally charge a person with committing a crime, as an indictment. This covers how grand juries work, what is allowed in a grand jury hearing, how to challenge their fairness, and how private or public they are.

Title: Procedure for filing habeas corpus petition
Definition: This category covers how a person can file a petition for habeas corpus, challenging their detention or imprisonment.

Title: Supporting a petition for habeas corpus
Definition: This category covers how one can support a suspect or defendant's petition for habeas corpus, to challenge if their detention is against the law.

Title: Opposing a petition for habeas corpus
Definition: This category covers how one can oppose a suspect or defendant's petition for habeas corpus, to challenge if their detention is against the law.

Title: Review of a habeas corpus petition
Definition: This category covers how a court will review a person's habeas corpus petition.

Title: Line-up procedures in a criminal investigation
Definition: This category covers the required procedure for line-ups of possible suspects and others, so that a witness or victim can identify them.

Title: Being investigated for a crime
Definition: This category covers situations in which a person may be a suspect for a crime, before they have been charged or indicted with a crime.  This covers how police may try to gather evidence, get statements, find witnesses, and get identifications. This covers what protections and procedure a person can expect.

Title: Misidentification during a line-up
Definition: This category covers situations in which a witness may have mistakenly identified someone in a line-up as someone responsible for a crime. This includes how the suspect can defend themselves and challenge the identification.

Title: Make motion for a new trial
Definition: This category covers how a person on trial for a crime can make a motion to ask for a new trial, based on some problem that has happened during the current one.

Title: Encounters with the police
Definition: This category covers what rights and options a person has when they interact with the police. This covers being stopped on foot, in a car, or other places. It also covers rights of someone who is a suspect or who is not.

Title: Police or prosecutors' misconduct
Definition: This category covers situations in which a person believes the police or prosecutor has behaved incorrectly or unethically. This covers what options there are for challenging misconduct, what procedure may result, and what outcomes may happen.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2042800], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2042899]

Title: Prosecutor failing to disclose evidence (Brady Violation)
Definition: This category covers situations in which a prosecutor or government agent fails to disclose evidence during a criminal proceeding, when that evidence could have materially favored the defendant. This is called a Brady violation, and it might be used to challenge the case and verdict by the defense.

Title: Misconduct cases against police or prosecutors
Definition: This category covers how a police officer or prosecutor may be investigated or sued for misconduct. This includes how a person may file a civil case against a police officer for misconduct.

Title: Juvenile Criminal Records
Definition: This category covers how records of criminal activity when a person was still a juvenile (not an adult) may be accessed, sealed, or kept confidential.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1490500], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1490504]

Title: Accessing a juvenile criminal record
Definition: This category covers how a person can access their own juvenile criminal record, or how others can access it.

Title: Confidentiality of juvenile criminal records
Definition: This category covers the rules about whether juvenile criminal records are protected as confidential or not.

Title: Expungement of juvenile criminal record
Definition: This category covers how a person can get their juvenile criminal record expunged, cleaned, or sealed.

Title: Requesting a jury for a criminal trial
Definition: This category covers how and when a criminal defendant can request to have a jury trial rather than bench trial, and what this choice means. It also covers the defendant's right to have a jury trial.

Title: Sentencing and penalties after being found guilty
Definition: This category covers how a person may be sentenced to jail, fines, and other penalties after having been found guilty at a criminal trial. It covers how the sentence is decided on, and how the defendant may try to challenge it.

Title: Sex Offender registration
Definition: This category covers obligations a person might have to register as a sex offender, after they've been found guilty of a crime. This covers how to register, penalties for not registering, and others' access to it.

Title: Innocence Commissions and laws
Definition: This category covers a person's options, after they've been found guilty of a crime, to challenge this conviction with the help of Innocence Commissions or laws that can review a case to stop wrongful convictions or execution of an innocent person.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2042920], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2042930]

Title: Deferred Action immigration status
Definition: This category covers options for an immigrant to get a Deferred Action status, that gives people who are in the US illegally an indefinite delay of their deportation. Deferred Action does not give an immigrant legal status

Title: Criminal conviction leading to deportation
Definition: This category covers if and how a criminal conviction can lead to an immigrant's removal from the United States. It covers the process by which a conviction can lead to deportation, and how a person can appeal or stop the deportation.

Title: Stopping deportation through Withholding of Removal
Definition: This category covers protections a person might have against being deported, particularly if their life or freedom would be threatened in the other country, on account of a protected ground, like race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or otherwise. This could be called 'withholding of removal' or 'non-refoulment'. This category covers how a person can try to use this process to stop their deportation or removal, and how the government will make a decision about it.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1810504], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1810850]

Title: Waivers of Inadmissibility, Deportation, or Removal
Definition: This category covers options for an immigrant to get a waiver from deportation or removal proceedings, or from decisions that they are inadmissible to the US. This waiver may provide them exceptions from the usual rules of deportability or inadmissibility

Title: Bond Hearing for a detained immigrant
Definition: This category covers the options for an immigrant who is being held in detention in the United States, to be released from detention through a bond hearing. This includes how to request a bond hearing, how the hearing will proceed, and what possible outcomes will result. It also covers the process of paying the bond and having this amount returned.

Title: Parole for immigrants
Definition: This category covers options for parole, for immigrants who are detained in the U.S. This is about how an immigrant can request parole, in order to be able to leave detention for a temporary period while their case is pending in immigration court. It coves who is eligible, what documents and evidence are needed, and what the terms of the parole will be.

Title: Discrimination against Immigrants
Definition: This category covers what rights and protections an immigrant might have if they face discrimination at work, at school, in the business, with the government, or otherwise.

Title: Legalization of undocumented immigrant
Definition: This category covers options for an undocumented immigrant in the United States to get a legal status that lets them stay legally. This could be for an immigrant who has entered the country illegally, or one who has overstayed another visa. This includes options for Dreamers, or people who are on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. It also includes asylum, U Visas, and other options for people in special situations.

Title: Immigrants working when undocumented or without authorization
Definition: This category covers rights and consequences of an immigrant in the US working, without legal status that allows them to work.

Title: Work as an immigrant
Definition: This category covers options, rights, and rules for immigrants in the U.S. who want to work. This includes how to get authorization to work, the visa statuses that allow work, and rules and penalties for violating rules around work.

Title: Sponsoring an immigrant for a work visa
Definition: This category covers options and procedure for a company or nonprofit that is considering sponsoring a work visa for immigrants to the United States. This covers what different work visas are, the process of being a sponsor, and what obligations and rules the sponsor must follow.

Title: Settlements, Mediation, and Diversion from Eviction
Definition: This category covers how an eviction may be averted, through a landlord and tenant settlement, mediation, diversion program, or prevention program.

Title: Income Taxes
Definition: This category covers how a person's income taxes are calculated and paid, to the federal and state government, based on money that they have made from wages, independent contractor work, royalties, interest, and other sources. It also covers what deductions and benefits might reduce the taxes owed.

Title: Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC)
Definition: This category covers the Earned Income Tax Credit to give low- to moderate-income people with money through a tax credit. This covers who is eligible for an EITC refund, how it is calculated, how family members and income levels affect it, and how to make a claim for EITC.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1291300], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [23], Legal Server Index Taxonomy [LS002-00024]

Title: Sales taxes
Definition: This category covers how a business can ensure they are complying with sales tax rules.

Title: Uniform Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act for servicemembers
Definition: This category covers military servicemembers' and veterans' rights under the Uniform Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act (USERRA). This includes obligations for employers to put servicemembers back in their civilian jobs after military service. It also is about how they can seek employment without discrimination based on their military service.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [ 1770800], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1770899]

Title: Reemployment after military service
Definition: This category covers military servicemembers' and veterans' reentry into the civilian workforce, and their rights around reemployment.

Title: Active duty claim for household goods
Definition: This category covers how a military servicemember can make claims for compensation for household goods that have been damaged, lost, or stolen.

Title: Active duty medical claims
Definition: This category covers how a military servicemember can make claims for compensation for medical issues, while they are on active duty.

Title: Administrative Discharge (being fired) from military service
Definition: This category covers situations in which a military servicemember is fired or given an administrative discharge. It includes how a person can dispute or appeal this discharge, or try to change its code or characterization.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1770200], NSMI v1 Taxonomy [1770299]

Title: Medical Discharge from military
Definition: This category covers what happens if a military service member is discharged from the military as a medical discharge, including with help around discharge upgrades or appeals, and when you may still be able to get to benefits.

Title: Changing a rental agreement or lease
Definition: This category covers how a tenant and landlord may make changes to a lease or rental agreement. This could be through a mediation to stop an eviction, or it could be because of an emergency like COVID-19.

Title: Voting Systems, Ballots, and Rules
Definition: This category covers rules about how a person can submit a ballot to vote in an election, including rules about mail-in ballots, in-person voting, provisional ballots, and other procedural concerns about participating in an election.

Title: Districting and Gerrymandering
Definition: This category covers how districts are created for elections, including concerns about gerrymandering or manipulation, and how to challenge districting plans.

Title: Copyright of written or artistic works
Definition: This category concerns how a person or business can protect their IP around written, dramatic, musical, software, and artistic works with copyright, or how another might challenge their copyright claims.

Title: Patents for an invention
Definition: This category covers how a person or business can protect their invention through a patent, including how to file for a patent and establish it. It also covers how to challenge a patent, or deal with those violating a patent.

Title: Trademarks for names and logos
Definition: This category covers how a person or a business can protect their brand and logo through a trademark, and how this might be challenged. It covers how a trademark is established, enforced, or challenged.

Title: Freedom of Information (FOIA) to request government info
Definition: This category is about how a person might request information from the government through a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request.

Title: Dealing with different branches of government
Definition: This category covers how a person can understand and deal with different levels and branches of the government.

Title: Dealing with federal agencies
Definition: This category covers how a person can understand and deal with the agencies of the federal government.

Title: Dealing with municipal government and ordinances
Definition: This category is about how a person can understand and deal with local, municipal government and ordinances.
Taxonomies: NSMI v1 Taxonomy [2090200], Legal Services Corporation Taxonomy [97]

Title: Dealing with state and local agencies
Definition: This category is about how a person can understand and deal with state and local government agencies.

Title: Dealing with state legislatures and courts
Definition: This category is about how a person can understand and deal with state legislatures and courts.

Title: Landlord harassment or problem behavior
Definition: This category is about situations where a landlord is behaving in a way that is threatening, harassing, or otherwise troubling for tenants.

Title: Ending a rental lease early
Definition: This category covers situations in which a landlord or tenant wants to end a rental agreement early, in order to have the tenant leave before the lease specifies.  This could be in situations where the tenant is unhappy with the housing, and wants to leave early. Or it could be when the landlord wants to have the tenant leave, even though the lease is for a longer term.

Title: Landlord suing tenant for money
Definition: This category covers situations when a landlord brings a lawsuit against present or past tenants, to recover money from them.  This could include attempts to recover rent that was not paid, penalties, fees, or other financial damages that the landlord believes they have suffered. This could be filed alongside an eviction lawsuit, or separate from it.

Title: Debt collection for medical costs
Definition: This category covers situations in which a person faces debt collection for medical or dental bills, including calls, letters, warnings, and lawsuits.
